dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON THE FACE OF JAMIE MCALLAN (Caucasian, 20's) Black eye. Cut lip. He looks like a beaten prize fighter who is dripping in sweat and mud. WIDEN TO REVEAL we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ash colored storm clouds make it look like night. Jam scrapes the muck off his shovel blade and resumes. The mu is so thick it’s like digging into raw meat. A distant lightning flash accompanied by THUNDER. Jamie u his urgency as he chops at the wet earth. An upside down face appears in the hole’s opening. It’s HENRY MCALLAN (Caucasian, late 40's), Jamie’s salt-of-the-earth, older brother. Henry is a man of few words who rarely smiles. They speak with the lilting garble of the Mississippi Del

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: My turn. Take a break.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We ain’t gonna make it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We will. We have to. Henry extends his hand and helps Jamie out of the hole. Then, as Henry maneuvers his way into the hole we see tha moves with a noticeable limp. Jamie pulls a handkerchief from his pocket and wipes mud from his face and hands. As watches Henry dig we hear Jamie’s VOICE OVER:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We will. We have to. That was my brother, Henry: absolutely certain whatever he wanted to happen would. The weather would dry out in time to resow the cotton. Next year would be a better year. We would get this hole dug before the storm hit. (beat) And his little brother would never betray him. LIGHTNING and THUNDER. Jamie looks up and sees angry, bla clouds eating up the sky. Then from inside the hole we he a CLANG as Henry’s shovel hits something hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Piece of rock, I think. Henry shoves his hand into the mud to pull out the rock. what he retrieves is actually a human skull missing a big chunk in the back. They trade a look. Henry keeps digging alternating between shovel and bare hands as he discovers rest of the skeleton. A collarbone, scapula and ribs.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Oh Lord... It ain’t right. This just ain’t right. Henry digs out the pelvis and leg bones. We hear a metall CLINK. Henry unearths the tibia and sees a crude, rusted iron shackle with a broken chain dangling from it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. This is a slave’s grave.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You don’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: See here? Shot in the head. Must’ve been a runaway. (extending a grimy hand) That settles it. Help me out.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Settles what?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I won’t bury our father in a slave’s grave. There’s nothing he would’ve hated more.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We don’t have a choice. More LIGHTNING and THUNDER. The brothers hold a look. Henry knows Jamie is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hole has grown longer and deeper and is now a foot ov Jamie's head - a proper grave. Henry’s face appears in th opening of the hole:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yep, that should do it. Jamie hands the shovel up. But then, when Henry tries to help Jamie out, it’s no use. The hole is too deep, their hands are too wet and the walls are too slick. HENRY (CONT’D) I'll fetch the ladder. Jamie nods and Henry moves off. As the squelch of Henry's boots steadily grows quiet we see the pain and worry in Jamie's eyes. All around him is oozing mud. And overhead a crude rectangle of darkening gray. Then we hear the staccato pitter-patter of RAIN DROPS. Ja looks up and they begin to hit his face. At first just a few, but then they come faster. Jamie tries to climb out again. But he slips back in. Another try and this time he almost makes it before sliding back down. Jamie's panic rises as he tries to claw out of the hole. it’s futile as his fingers cut through the mud like butte

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Henry! HENRY!! The rain falls harder as the storm hits it’s stride. And hole is already starting to fill with water. Jamie’s eyes grow wild as he suddenly throws himself against the walls like a trapped animal.

dialogues.speaker: ON HENRY
dialogues.text: As he limps back towards the hole with the ladder, he hea Jamie screaming.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Henry hustles back to the hole but Jamie is too frantic t notice.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Jamie!! Jamie, I’m here!!  Jamie snaps out of it as Henry lowers the ladder. Jamie scrambles up and promptly doubles over trying to quell th panic.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you decided to leave me down there.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why would I do that? Jamie glances up. Henry’s looking at him like he’s crazy. Jamie hauls up the ladder and moves off:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Come on. Let’s get this over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PAPPY MCALLAN (60'S), eyes closed, his expression tranquil. He is dressed as we will see him throughout, in his Sunday best. WIDEN TO REVEAL Jamie and Henry standing over him. Henry pulls a sheet over Pappy’s face then rega the ramshackle coffin made of mismatched scrap wood.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I wish to hell we’d been able to get to town. Jamie moves to Pappy’s feet and Henry to his head as they to putting the body in the coffin. As they lift:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gently now.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Right, wouldn’t want to hurt him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (sharp) That’s not the point.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, brother. I’m just tired. With ludicrous care they lower the corpse into the box. Henry reaches for the lid and starts to put it on:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Go on. I'll finish up here.  5. Jamie nods and throws a last look at the corpse. We STAY him as he drifts outside to the porch. A HAMMER STRIKING NAIL gives him pause. He produces an almost empty bottle bourbon from his back pocket. He downs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain and wind have slowed down. ON A PAIR OF BOOTS as they trudge through thick, ankle-deep mud. WIDEN TO REVEA that the boots belong to LAURA MCALLAN (Caucasian, 30's). She follows Jamie and Henry who carry the coffin. Laura i more plain than pretty and there’s a tired strength in he eyes. She stumbles in the muck and we hear her VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I think of the farm I think of mud. Encrusting knees and hair. Marching in boot shaped patches across the floor. I dreamed in brown. The procession arrives at the grave. Henry and Jamie set coffin down and work ropes underneath it as Laura looks o The ropes slip, the coffin tumbles to the ground. Wood GROANS and there’s a loud CRACK from inside.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dammit.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What if we stand at either end and run the ropes lengthwise?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Coffin’s too narrow. It falls again it could break open. Jamie shrugs, “so what?” HENRY (CONT’D) No. Laura reacts to a mule pulled wagon she sees approaching.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: The Jacksons. As the wagon gets closer we see the JACKSONS: HAP and FLORENCE ride up front with their youngest RUEL (10). Beh them their children, MARLON (15) and LILLY MAY (12). Henr moves towards them:

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Henry, don’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S’not my fault what happened.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Just let them go.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Leaving us in the middle of the season? Least they can do is lend a hand. Laura and Jamie trade a look as Henry waves the wagon dow Hap’s eyes are tight and cold as he clucks the horses to stop. Laura ventures a nod at Florence, Florence ignores

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you help us out here? Hap considers Jamie. The cracked coffin sinking into the

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hap? Florence puts a hand on Hap’s hand. They look to each oth for an answer that isn’t there. Laura shifts her weight, looks away from Henry.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was a thirty one year old virgin when I met Henry McAllan in the Spring of 1939.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON LAURA, mud-free and squeaky clean. She is smiling coyl and we WIDEN TO REVEAL that she’s sitting across from Hen who is quiet and inscrutable throughout. The other guests the dinner table: Laura’s brother, TEDDY (late 20’s) and MOTHER and FATHER (50's). This place is a sharp contrast the farm. It’s light and pristine with clean napkins and crisp, white shirts. Laura’s V.O.:

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I lived with my parents in the house I grew up in. My world was small and he was my rescuer from a life in the margins. Laura’s mother has sniffed out the sparks between Laura a Henry. Mom gives Henry the hard sell with a smile as Laur squirms in the spotlight.  LAURA’S MOTHER Oh, an engineering degree from Ole Miss? Laura’s a college graduate, got her teaching certificate from West Tennessee State.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear sister’s the smartest one in the family. Made better grades than I ever did. (winking to Henry) Never heard the end of it. LAURA’S MOTHER Laura, why don’t you play some piano after dinner. (to Henry re: Laura) You really must hear her sing. (to Laura) You should play something for Mr. McAllan later.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Momma. LAURA’S MOTHER How about that hymn y’all did at service last Sunday? Or Ave Maria, that’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Momma.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m quite sure that Teddy did not bring his new boss, Mr. McAllan, over to hear hymns. LAURA’S MOTHER Well, let’s ask him then. Mr. McAllan, would you like to hear some music later? Eyes turn to Henry as he finishes a bite of food and wipe his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I like hymns. Laura, de-centered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura opens the door to REVEAL Henry with a bouquet of flowers. She smiles, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was unused to male admiration and knew only that I wanted more. It was at least a reprieve from the sincere pity and insincere kindness directed at old maids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura and Henry gazing at the big screen. She steals a glance at him.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He didn’t feel the need to fill the air with words like I did. He had the self confidence I lacked. He was, after all, a veteran of the Great War.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Laura walk hand in hand. The dogwood trees are blooming and flurries of white petals flit on gentle bree Henry picks a petal out of Laura’s hair and they hold a l

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Though he never spoke of it, his limp was a constant reminder of his brave sacrifice. I can’t say that I was truly in love with him, but I was so grateful to him it dwarfed everything else... Henry takes her face in his hands, grinds a kiss onto her mouth. Laura recovers, tries a smile, waits for some tenderness, a grand romantic declaration--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: My brother, Jamie’s coming up from Oxford in a few weeks. I’d like for him to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura and Henry in the center of the BUZZING terminal. La is dressed for the occasion. Henry paces, excited. A LOUDSPEAKER announces the train’s arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Right on time. That’s rare for Jamie. Henry scans the crowd, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. Henry points. Jamie strides through the crowd. He is fres clean, beautiful. Henry moves to him as fast as limp will permit. A warm, rocking hug. They step back and study eac other’s faces.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You look good, brother.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Likewise.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: The air up here in Memphis agrees with you. (looking at Laura) Or is it something else? Jamie throws Laura a movie star smile. And she is immediately taken by his charm.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: This is Miss Chappell. (to Laura) My brother, Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: The pleasure is all mine. With exaggerated gallantry, Jamie takes Laura’s offered h and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He thinks he’s a character in one of his plays.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Henry tells me you’re studying theater at Ole Miss.  10.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (forefinger in the air) Ah, but which play, dear brother? Hamlet? Faust? Prince Hal?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Hopefully one of them fellas can earn you a decent wage someday.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What do you think, Miss Chappell?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I think you’re more of a Puck. Jamie is impressed and the dazzle in his smile shows it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Dear lady, thou speakest right. I am that merry wanderer of the night.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Who’s Puck?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (mock despair) Lord what fools these mortals be. Despite being older, Henry has always been in Jamie’s sha

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Puck’s a kind of mischievous sprite.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: A hobgoblin. Forgive me, I’m only trying to impress her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Laura’s not the impressionable type.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Good for her. Jamie smiles and winks at Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WELL-HEELED GUESTS lounging on Queen Anne couches. BLACK SERVANTS buzz about with trays. A BLACK BIG BAND plays something watered-down swing.  11. Laura, Henry and Jamie giggling in a lush nook. Jamie is story. Laura is rapt. Henry’s heard it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Next thing I knew I was sucked under, concussed and bleeding, I was as good as gone. Another victim of the great flood of twenty- seven.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you never told me this. (to Jamie) Then what happened?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I saw a glimmering light. Like a fallen star. (wiggling his fingers) And a great big hand reached out of it. Thought it was God himself come to take me. But it wasn’t. It was my dear big brother, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (smiling to Henry) You saved his life. You’re a hero.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He is indeed.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What else was I supposed to do? Let him drown? It’s not a pleasant memory for Henry. As he shrugs it off SERVANT refreshes their champagne. HENRY (CONT’D) That’11 do--

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We've barely had any. Don’t worry Henry, I’ve got more stamina than you-— Jamie tips the servant’s hands, extends the pour.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What, from modeling clothes? Don’t know how you do that. Seems so undignified for a man.  12.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We'll have plenty of time later for you to evaluate my life choices, brother. Tonight, we celebrate. (raising his glass) Here’s to the future. Whatever it may hold. May you be blessed with happiness, health, prosperity and... (to Henry re: Laura) ...-if she’ll have you, maybe even a house full of children. My love to you both. Said genuinely. Laura is touched. Despite himself, Henry too. They clink glasses and drink.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Ooh, bubbly. Just then the band switches the beat and ups volume. It’s time to dance. As couples start to move to the dance floo Jamie looks to Henry:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Would you mind terribly if I hada dance with your girl? (off Henry’s shrug) Miss Chappell? Care to take a spin? Laura looks to Henry, Henry nods.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Jamie and Laura whirl. Jamie’s got Fred Astaire moves. Bu this is new to Laura and she’s awkward. Jamie patiently leads and soon Laura's swept off her feet. For a while it feels like it’s just the two of them out there.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jamie saw in a different way. When his eyes were on me, I felt like I was no longer invisible. Laura and Jamie lock eyes and the connection is overwhelm The envious eyes of other women in the room. Laura shrugs off Henry’s questioning gaze. The song ends. Laura is breathless.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Jamie escorts Laura back to the table. She’s flushed. Hen notices it.  13.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I’11 be back. Jamie moves off and Henry looks to Laura.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You look especially pretty tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Jamie has that effect on girls. They sparkle for him. (beat) He likes you. I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m sure he doesn’t dislike anyone.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: At least not anyone in a skirt. (re: the dance floor) See what I mean? Laura looks and sees Jamie on the dance floor with a PRET GIRL. The girl effortlessly follows Jamie through a serie of turns and dips. Laura suddenly feels foolish and tries cover it as she sips her champagne glass empty. Henry ref it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Henry's marriage proposal didn’t play out like I'd pictured it would. He wasn’t kneeling and the question actually came out as more of a statement. Henry wasn’t a romantic. He was made of sturdier stuff. But he was a good, hard working man. And he loved me. And I knew that he would provide, be true, and give me children. And for that, I could certainly love him in return. Laura steals glances at Jamie dancing and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. HENRY/LAURA’S MEMPHIS HOUSE - DAY Henry carries Laura over the threshold.  14.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I loved domestic life. Then, in a MONTAGE we see Laura around the house cooking, ironing, cleaning and being domestic.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yielding to Henry and waiting for him to come home to me was what I'd been put on earth to do. CUT TO: Laura holding INFANT AMANDA LEIGH as they finish dinner . Henry insists that she stay seated as he cleans up the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And when Amanda Leigh was born I became hers completely. Another CUT and Laura plays blocks on the floor with now ONE-YEAR-OLD AMANDA LEIGH while Henry tunes the radio.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But then came the day that changed everything. Forever... We PUSH IN on the radio as we hear Franklin Delano Roosev

dialogues.speaker: FDR, (ON THE RADIO)
dialogues.text: Mister Vice President, Mister Speaker, members of the Senate and of the House of Representatives. Yesterday, December 7th, 1941, a date which will live in infamy, the United States of America was suddenly and deliberately attacked by naval and air forces of the Empire of Japan. EXT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Daddy borrowed Mister Robert’s and ‘nems truck to take me. That’s what I remember most. The first things and the last things stick the hardest. A gathering of NEIGHBORS in the tidy yard. Ronsel in cris TRAVELING CLOTHES, his sister, Lilly May, hanging on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: Don’t forget about us.  15.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: You know I won’t. Marlon steps forward with a brave face, pumps his brother hand, claps his back. Little brother Ruel follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: Take care Ron.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Y'all don’t be quarreling. Pitch in good, help Mama ‘nem.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: We will.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: And keep them no ‘count boys away from Lilly May. Don’t let her turn fast. Lilly May smiles through her sniffles, pops Ronsel on the shoulder as she steps back. Marlon does a little salute. looks on from the driver's seat of his rough-idling truck pride and doubt competing for his eyes. Ronsel slings his pack over his shoulder, ambles over to where Florence holds herself against the cab. She puts he hand on his forehead, cups his face, holds her hand over beating heart. Bomp. Bomp. Bomp. He’s alive. Ronsel holds Florence's hand over his heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You just come back.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: I will Mama.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You come all the way back. Ronsel kisses her hand. Florence pats his chest and peels herself away. Neighbors and family surge forward as Hap e the truck away, spill into the dirt road waving and whistling. But Florence doesn’t look back.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can’t look back. I didn’t look back. It’s bad luck to watch somebody leave.  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence opening the windows, chasing out dust. Exorcisin fear from the corners of the cabin with her broom.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I held his heartbeat in my hand. I remember every beat. He was warm and alive. I know every place in him. Florence throws open the back door. Beyond a small green garden, COTTON FIELDS stretch infinitely from her yard po Hap and Marlon are slow-moving specks on the horizon. Florence raises her hand in a wave.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And it was all I could do to not look back. One of the specks waves back.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, I don’t have favorites. INT. HAP’S CHURCH - DAY Hap in the pulpit, sweating and quaking and exalting. Swa trees visible through the missing boards behind him. A br blowing in through an empty window pane. Florence in the front row, flanked by her children, duly listening. Her e closed.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I love them all equally. Every mother does. But during all those four years, all that time he was gone... Florence’s eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I only prayed for him. Hap catches Florence’s eye, shoots her a smile.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: God'1l forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: John 14:1-3 “In my Father’s house, are many mansions. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hap, head words. Hap lifts the crowd, The words 16A.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If it were not so I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you... that’s where I am, ye may be also.” (beat) I know that brings me comfort. It brings me comfort that One Morning My getting up is gonna be just a little bit easier than the day before. One Morning My children are not gonna wake up in this place, they’re gonna open they eyes on a new sky. One Morning We gonna knock the boot from off our neck, we gonna shake the chains from round our feet. Oh Yes One morning! And I’m not talking about the hereafter. I’m talking about the Right Now! Oh One Morning! I said One morning Soon... (song) hung low, is silent. Speechless, searching for

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: That’s all right, sir. Take your time! his heartbroken eyes to the congregation. He scans looking for a reason. His eyes catch on Florence. still don’t come.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Church. ..Beloved. I don’t know I just don’t know. (beat) You see how they done him? Y'all seen how they done him. Father I Stretch My Hand To Thee

dialogues.speaker: A FIELD OF COTTON
dialogues.text: The shadow of a biplane crop duster BUZZES across fields.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The army made Jamie a bomber pilot. But it’s my fault he’s up there.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HENRY’S CAR (MOVING) - DAY - SIMULATANEOUS Henry drives on the road adjacent to the cotton field. As the plane roars past his VOICE OVER continues:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When Jamie was a boy he had questions about my time in the Great War. How many Huns did I kill? How had I been injured? Why did they call it great? And all I could do was make him promise that if he ever had to be a soldier he would get up to the sky. They say battle is cleaner in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, Laura, 2 YEAR OLD AMANDA LEIGH, and INFANT ISABELL finish breakfast. Henry kisses all his girls good-bye. He rolls a sheath of BLUEPRINTS, stuffs them in a tube stamp ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS. Grabs a construction helmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of TODDLERS ride the long tail their MOTHER’S COTT SACK. The mother picks and steps, picks and steps in automated drudgery. SHIFF SHIFF SHIFF. The babies gliding backwards on their mother’s effort. Other PICKERS in wear synchrony in the rows alongside her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Work kept me from my family. But the army needed bases and airfields and I was happy to oblige. My great- great grand daddy and his slaves built the farm I grew up on.  18. Henry leans next to his idling car, a worn NO TRESPASSING sign hangs limp from a tree. Henry eyes a string of dista SHARECROPPERS. He reaches down and grabs a handful of ear

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One time Grandaddy told me to go grab up a handful of dirt from the yard, and I did. He asks me “What are you holding?" I said “Dirt”. He says “that's right now give it to me." So I do and he says “Now what's this I've got in my hand?" “Dirt” , I says. Then he says “Naw boy, this is LAND I've got. Do you know why?" Henry sniffs the dirt in his hands, tastes it, spits it o

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And he says “because I OWN it. It's mine. And one day it'll be yours. But in the meantime, to you and every other person who doesn't own it, it’s just dirt.” Henry tosses the dirt away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight beams through stained glass and a preacher resid over a small congregation. Henry, Laura, Amanda Leigh (4) and Isabelle (2), walk down the aisle followed by Pappy. HENRY’S MOTHER lies in repose. Laura moves past the caske quickly with the children in tow.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Except that land never became mine. Pappy sold it after the flood. He told people that the river wiped him out. But that was a lie. Pappy stops and takes a long look down at the body. Henry lays a flower in the casket. Pappy sobs heavily as he wri the hat he holds in his hands. Henry starts to reach for father’s shoulder, hesitates, clasps his hands behind him instead.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He walked away from that land gladly. Another PARISHIONER drapes a comforting arm around Pappy.  19.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And when mama died, he sold my dreams as payment for his grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Henry and Laura make love. Henry climaxes, then slo rolls off of her. They both catch their breath and stare the ceiling for several post-coital beats, then:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Honey, by the way. I bought a farm in Mississippi. Laura’s head snaps towards him, her face smeared with sho But Henry continues like it’s great news:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s 40 miles south of Greenville near a town called Marietta. We’ll be moving in three weeks time.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: When did you do this?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Just recently. I rented us a house in town. It’s a gorgeous with a big old porch, an oak tree, four bedrooms. You and the girls will love it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: But we love this house.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: They each get their own room and Pappy can have his own space.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Pappy?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Of course. Now that momma’s gone someone's got to look after him. (then) Wait ‘til you see it. It’s gota modern electric stove. And it’s only 3 blocks from the elementary school. And it’s only about a half hour drive out to the farm. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bought it from a couple who lost their son in the war. Felt bad taking it at such a low price, but they wanted out. (then) I'll have Pappy drive the truck up next week.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What truck?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The pick up I bought to use on the farm. Got a tractor too. John Deere Model B. Helluva machine. I’ll be able to farm a hundred acres by myself. Imagine that. Henry realizes Laura has been looking at him, agape.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're mighty quiet.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm mighty surprised.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But you knew I always intended to have my own farm someday. I’m sure I mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, Henry. I had no idea. I would’ve remembered that.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well. I’m telling you now. We've got ourselves two hundred acres of fertile land. And with that tractor I don’t need a bunch of sharecroppers, I can do most of the work myself.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What about my family?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Me and the girls are your family.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I mean my mother and father.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: They can visit. You can too.  21.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: But...three weeks?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Laura, honey, in a year’s time I'll turn enough profit to buy us another hundred acres. Man up the road is itching to sell. Lot better living than I’m making now. (then) You're going to love it. I know you will. You’ll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find the McAllan convoy leaving town. Laura drives the DeSoto sedan with Isabelle and Amanda Leigh. Henry and Pa are in a pick-up truck packed full of belongings includin Laura’s piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two-car McAllan convoy rolls by. It’s much more ru out here and a world away from Memphis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s even more charming than Henry described. The process unfolds from the caravan. Henry watches Laura as she takes it in. She looks at Henr and softens, the house is lovely. He moves to her and tak her hand as they walk towards their new home.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA LEIGH
dialogues.text: Mommy flowers!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I see, honey. (to Henry) You didn’t tell me we had azaleas.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So we do. Isabelle coughs as she curls deeper into mommy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She's done in. Let’s get inside.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Key should be under the mat.  22. Just then the the front door opens to REVEAL a big, bear man, ORRIS STOKES (Caucasian, 30's). He’s not friendly.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We’re the McAllans. The new tenants of this house. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Orris Stokes. The new owner of this house.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I rented this place from George Suddeth just three weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Suddeth sold me the house last week. And he didn’t say nothing ‘bout no renters.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Is that a fact? I guess I need to refresh his memory.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: He left town three days ago.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I gave him a hundred dollar deposit.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You get anything in writing?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We shook on the deal. Pappy spits on the ground, shakes his head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I paid him a hundred dollars cash right there in the living room. I had dinner with him and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: You best be getting on. Orris shuts the door behind him.  23.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You got swindled, boy. Damn fool. Henry is crestfallen. Another cough from Isabelle. Off th whole group looking to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Then we’ll have to stay on the farm. There’s a house. We can make it work.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You mean out there with the niggers and the farm hands?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s the only place big enough for all of us. There’s nothing else in town. Believe me, I looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The McAllan’s two-car convoy rocks and bumps their way do the road. The land is flat and mostly featureless. Africa American men, women and children dot the fields, tilling earth with mule drawn plows. Eventually they pass run down sharecropper’s shacks with yards. African American women hang clothes on lines as children play or watch the procession from porches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hap surveys his land. Ruel and Marlon toil shoulder to shoulder in the fading light. Florence and Lily May chip at the day’s chores.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What good is a deed? My grandfathers and great-uncles, grandmothers and grand-aunts, father and mother--broke, tilled, toiled, planted, plucked, razed, burned, broke again. Worked this land all their lives. This land that would never be theirs. They worked until they sweated. They sweated until they bled. They bled until they died. Died with the dirt of this same 200 acres underneath they fingernails. Died, clawing at the hard brown back that would never be theirs. All they deeds undone. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) Yet this man, this place, this law, say you need a deed. All the blood and sweat and dying with dirt under your fingernails don’t count. Doesn’t make it yours. Say you need a deed, not Deeds. So what good is a deed? A deed is a piece of paper. One of my great-uncles, Uncle William, got ahold of a piece of land during reconstruction. A good piece of land right next to the river. He had a deed. Had his piece of paper and all. Four white men rode up on horses one day, aimed they pistols, said it was theirs. My uncle’s good deed torn into forty pieces and thrown to the wind. It was too good, you see? The land he had claimed. And so I ask: what good is a deed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bridge spans a small river. As the two-car convoy dri over the creaky structure Henry leans his head out the wi and shouts back to Laura in the DeSoto.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: This is it! We’re on our land now!

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pride goeth before destruction and a haughty spirit before a fall. Hap leads his MULE into the stall, gives its mane a good before tying a feed bag on.  24.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That mule made me a share tenant, not a share cropper. And it had me dreaming about having my own piece of land. Maybe that’s where the problem started. Hap saunters back to his cabin, luxuriates in the calm of completed day’s work. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - SUNSET Hap and his family shoulder to shoulder around an overflo dinner table. Cabbage and onions from Florence’s garden. cast iron skillet with rabbit in heavy brown gravy. A pla of sliced tomatoes goes around. A SURVEYOR’S MAP with outlined parcels is pinned to the wall. A pencil on a str hangs from a nail next to it. Hap stares at it as he eats Hap leaps up, napkin still tucked around his neck to redr boundary, scribble notes.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: If only fences could be put up with lead.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: The get taken down with lead all the time. Hap winks at Florence, Florence blushes.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: Won’t be too much longer, Papa will it? This time next year I’ma have about fifty acres of cotton, fifty acres of oats, fifty acres of rice--

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: Fool, rice don’t grow here.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Never call your brother a fool.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: Well I’ma grow it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: That’s why I’m not gon’ be no farmer, I’ma be a stenographer.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: A ste- what?  25.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: It’s kinda like a typist.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: They don’t allow no colored typists.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Your sister will be the first.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: And? You'll be buying all your food from us. We gon’ get all your typist money.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: Nuh -unh. ‘Cause I’ma be in California or Chi-cago where all the good jobs at.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: War gonna be over by then.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: No it won’t-- Sudden silence settles over the group. LILLY MAY (CONT’D) I mean...but Ronsel, he--he’1l probably be home Mama.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: I don’t want him back early. Early means-—- Hap massages Florence’s shoulders, kisses her temple.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: He’s not coming back early. Y'all finish up. Get these dishes rinsed off before bed-- BANG BANG BANG from the door at the far side of the cabin All eyes on Hap. The dividing wall between what was a two family unit has been cut and framed with a door that exte the Jacksons cozy living space. BANG BANG BANG. Marlon st to rise, Hap motions him to sit. Hap palms a MACHETE that leans just inside the door, holds it close behind his leg before cracking opening it. Henry, fist still raised in a knock squinting back at his ragtag caravan.  26.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Evening, Mister. Henry swivels back around.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Henry McAllen. You Hap?

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Yes Sir?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We just rolled in, I’ma need you to unload. Hap taking in the scene, catching up.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: You’re the new owner. Thought you all wasn’t coming until next week.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I wanna get unloaded and the fire going before dark. Henry strides off to the car, doesn’t wait for a response doesn’t need. Hap looks at Florence, knowing glances. EXT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Then let him walk. Lilly May and Marlon lingering in the doorway. Hap at the truck pretending not to hear.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s too far and we don’t have time. It’ll be night soon.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: I ain’t movin’ for no nigger.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He can’t ride alone with Laura and the girls. And there’s no room in the back of the truck. (off Pappy) Pappy. Please. As Pappy gets out of the truck he eyes Hap. Hap lowers hi gaze. Off Laura and the girls watching the scene...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hap bounces uncomfortably between Henry and Pappy. Hap lo down and sees that his hand is ever so close to Pappy’s. shifts and we hear his VOICE OVER:

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mist McAllan was from Memphis and my guess was he didn’t know the eating end of a mule from the crapping end. Told me he intends to bring in one of them infernal tractors. Imagine that, using a machine to work his land instead of the hands the Lord gave him. This man put three families off on account of that damn tractor. But I thank God we wasn’t one of them. Most times a landlord puts the colored families off first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is a large rickety shack with a deserted air. I has a warped tin roof and shuttered windows with neither glass nor screens. A porch runs the length of the house a connects it to a small lean-to. There is a dirt yard with pump. A barn, pig wallow, chicken coop and a pasture. The two car convoy rolls to a ragged stop. Henry, Laura, Pappy, Hap, Amanda Leigh and Isabelle pile out. Laura is mortified. So is Pappy. Amanda Leigh goes running.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA LEIGH
dialogues.text: Will we have chickens, daddy?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You bet. Pigs too. A recent rain has turned the ground to muck. Laura steps into an ankle-deep mud puddle and loses her footing. She sucks her foot out, her nice shoes are ruined.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: You alright, Ms. McAllan?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm fine, thank you. Henry swoops Amanda Leigh into his arms and continues, th it’s more for Laura’s benefit:  28.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You know what else, jitter bug? That river we crossed over? I bet it’s full of catfish and crawdads.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Better git ‘im to replace them shutters or we might freeze to death.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: I thought you was planning to live in town, suh.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Plans changed.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA LEIGH
dialogues.text: Momma, I have to tinkle.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay, sweetheart, come on. Laura starts heading towards the house but Henry stops he

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Uh, honey, it’s around back.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Around back?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s an outhouse. There’s no...indoor plumbing. Henry points to a water pump not far off. Laura is incredulous. Henry’s eyes urge her to make the best of it Hap’s presence makes Henry squirm even more. Thunder rumb in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roof leaks in several spots. Henry and Hap back in wi Laura’s piano. Pappy sits on a rocking chair, smoking as watches.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Relax yourself Pappy. We got it. Laura bustles out of one of the bedrooms. She rifles thro a box.  29.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: The girls are done in. I need their blankets. As Laura tries to get to a particular chest she accidenta knocks over a box of books and they go tumbling out. Hap rushes over and helps pick the books up.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just stack them in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. (then reading the titles) A Tale of Two Cities. Wuthering Heights.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You can read?

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: My son, Ronsel, taught me. He over there fighting under General Patton.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You mean diggin’ ditches and peelin’ potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: No, suh, he a tank commander.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Ain’t no way the Army would turn a tank worth thousands of dollars over to a nigger. Now my son, Jamie, there’s a fightin’ man. He’s flying bombers.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: My son’s a sergeant. 761st battalion. Calls ‘em the black panthers.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Hey, hey boy! You know this one! Whaddya you call a nigger with stripes? (beat) A ra-COON! Hahahaha! Pappy enjoys his joke. Hap lowers his eyes and keeps pack up the books.  30.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Where you want this piano?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Let me get the girls to bed first--

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Ain’t no room for that piano. The hell am I gonna sleep?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Guess we'll have to put you in the lean-to?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: I ain’t sleeping out there, it don’t even have a floor. Laura turns her back on Pappy and softens her voice.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Henry, please--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There’s no room in the house.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: If you got rid of that piano we could put a bed right there.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: True. We could.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We. Need. The. Piano.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: We could rig a curtain around it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There’s an idea --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don’t want a bedroom in the middle of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: So you just puttin’ me out?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We’re not putting you out. (to Laura) Now, honey --  31.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: When you told me you were bringing to this Godforsaken place, I barely said a word. When you informed me that he was coming to live with us, I went along.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Laura-—

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And when Orris Stokes told you you'd been fleeced by that man you rented the house from, I kept my mouth shut. But I_am telling you now, we are not getting rid of that piano. It’s the one civilized thing in this place. So your father can either sleep in the lean-to or he can sleep in the bed with you, because I am not staying here without my piano. A silent showdown with Henry and Laura.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're overtired.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No. I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pappy unrolling his bed.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: God-DAMMIT.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: “Dear family. I'm writing to you from a village in Belgium called... (pronouncing phonetically) .--Tillet. Belgium is a country just north of France and it's beautiful. Daddy you would like it here. There are lots of farms... The sun is high and warm. WEARY SOLDIERS and the ravages war are everywhere. RONSEL sits atop his tank, writing a letter. His tank is dirty and as beat up as he is.  32.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ve been keeping busy, mostly training and looking for Germans. Luckily we haven’t seen too many. That’s clearly a lie as Ronsel eyes a red-crossed ambulan full of wounded soldiers driving by. He continues writing

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Of course, by the time you get this, I'll probably be long gone from here. We seem to always be on the move. A gruff SERGEANT (Caucasian) comes marching down the line

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Man all guns! Let’s move! Ronsel pockets his pencil and letter then bangs on the ha A head pops out, this is WEEKS (African American, 20's).

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soldiers march along, a column of tanks rolls by. Rons rides, his top half up outside the hatch. A DRONING BUZZ catches his ear and he looks up and spots a formation of bombers flying high above. Then Ronsel reacts to a Caucas SOLDIER who marches past:

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Hey, jig. Wha’ch you doing up in that tank, boy? Be careful, might hurt yourself! Ronsel eyes him as he rolls on, eventually passing a sign that points towards: MUNICH 10 km.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But when we do get a chance to set for a spell, the locals treat us real nice. They’re not like white folks back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a bouquet of flowers, a cleaned up Ronsel knocks on door and waits.  33. Then a pretty German girl (RESL, 20's) answers and smiles she’s been expecting him. He presents the flowers and she hugs him. The hug turns into a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm mighty grateful for that. I get homesick, and they do what they can to make us feel right at home. As Ronsel and Resl kiss we PRELAP the sounds of BATTLE. INT. RONSEL’S TANK - DAY We hear the PINGS and PANGS of bullets ricochetting off t armor. It’s claustrophobic and hot in here as Ronsel and 4 other African-American crew members operate like finger a hand. Ronsel is the commander, CLEVE is the driver and Weeks is the gunner.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Panzer, one o’clock!

dialogues.speaker: WEEKS
dialogues.text: Identified! I got him!

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Fire! The shell is loaded and BOOM. From Ronsel’s POV through t view finder, we see the German tank get hit and blow up.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Woo! Nice shot! Weeks smiles for a moment, then contorts his face as he R A LONG FART. The guys in the tank react.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE
dialogues.text: Goddamn, Weeks.

dialogues.speaker: WEEKS
dialogues.text: It’s them C-rations. Franks and beans.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: We should load you in the gun and fire you at the Jerries, they'd surrender quick. The whole crew busts up laughing. But the laughter is cut short by a VIOLENT BLAST. Shrapnel flies and metal twists Weeks absorbs the blow and gets most of his head blown of Ronsel gets knocked back and splattered by blood and brai  34. Then there is RINGING and BLURRED FOCUS as Ronsel gets hi bearings. Soon he comes to and sees a FIRE in the tank.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get outta the tank! Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Machine gun fire. Ronsel, Cleve and the other two tankers scramble out of the burning tank into a raging battle. Th slide out and hunker down against the tank for cover, pin Ronsel checks and cocks his .45. As bullets thud and whiz Ronsel looks to the sky. He sees a lone B-25 bomber trail thick, black smoke as it limps home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Jamie, blind-flying, cold wind whistling in through th window, snot and tears drying backwards over his face. Desperate as he struggles with the throttle of the shudde bomber, Jamie is splattered in blood and some of the cock windows have been shot out. Jamie looks over at his CO-PI who is slumped, dead and bloody. His eyes are drawn out the window, PARACHUTISTS escaping another plane. Jamie rolls his plane away from the sound gunfire. The parachutists are shot limp, dead men floatin gently on full sails. Jamie’s eyes brush a blood splattered picture of a pin-up girl stuck to the co-pilot’s side of the dashboard. It’s pretty red-head and there are handwritten words that read ‘LADY LUCK’. Off Jamie’s hand wrestling with the shaking throttle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie stares at the co-pilot’s empty bunk across from him The bed is neatly made. There’s a black and white photo o woman holding an infant among other personal effects. Laughter and carousing from OTHER SOLDIERS outside the th walls. Jamie pours himself a drink with a shaking hand, a lonely toast to surviving. Jamie is red-eyed, fights tear as we PRELAP the GROWL OF AN ENGINE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. THE MCALLAN FARM — DAY HENRY’S TRACTOR GROWLING across an empty, ready to be pla field. There’s satisfaction and hope in his eyes as he surveys the expanse of his land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hap hoes at the earth with Sisyphean determination. He st to wipe sweat from his brow and sees Marlon shirtless chopping alongside him, straining to keep up. Then he see Florence in the distance hanging laundry on a line. Lily feeding the chickens in the coop. Hap resumes his assault the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where CARL ATWOOD (Caucasian, 30’s) leans against a tree sipping from a flask. He grunts at his very pregnant wife VERA (Caucasian, 30's) as she carries a heavy pail of wat

dialogues.speaker: ATWOOD
dialogues.text: You better go slop them hogs. INT. HENRY’S PICK-UP TRUCK - CONTINUOUS As Henry glides by and sees Atwood sitting as Vera carrie her bucket. Atwood trots out to the road, Henry slows the to a polite roll but doesn’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: CARL ATWOOD
dialogues.text: You the new bossman hunh? Carl. Name’s Carl Atwood. Carl juts a dirty, nail-bitten hand into the cab. Henry h his breath as he shakes it. CARL ATWOOD (CONT’D) Well you need anything you call me. I’m yer number one man, you hear what I’m saying? Can’t depend on a nigger to do a white man’s job. Me and my wife--that’s Vera back ‘ere-- we been here for awhile. We’ll gitcha acquainted. And listen I know now’s not the right time, but whenever you get settled in I do needa talk t’you ‘bout a new contract. ‘Bout a raise? Last owner said--  36.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I’1ll catch you later Carl. Henry speeds away, leaves Carl in the dust. Carl waves af the truck.

dialogues.speaker: CARL ATWOOD
dialogues.text: ‘Salright I know yer busy! Nice speaking witcha Henry! Carl’s smile drains as soon as Henry’s truck disappears o the hill. He spits in the tire track. EXT. THE MCALLAN FARM — DAY A mass of dark rain clouds in the distance. A distant BOL OF LIGHTNING cracks the sky. A few beats later, THUNDER RUMBLES. Then slowly, rain starts to fall. A drizzle at first, then heavier and heavier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry HAMMERS repairs. Outside it’s raining sheets. Then, through the open doors, we see Pappy, shoulders hunched against the elements, as he hurries toward the barn. Papp arrives and shouts over the steady bang of Henry’s hammer

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Henry! Your wife wants you. Isabel’s worse and the other one’s comin’ down with it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Henry busts in to find Laura tending to Amanda Leig and Isabelle. Isabelle is lethargic, sweaty and wheezing her lips are blue. Amanda Leigh is more alert but coughin badly. Laura is frantic:

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s whooping cough. Go bring the doctor. And tell your father to put water on to boil. (off Henry’s pause) Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pouring rain as Henry runs out of the house and into the truck. He pulls out, tires spinning in the mud.  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Henry drives, concern all over his face. Then he reacts to something he sees through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry pulls up. The river ROARS and is completely flooded The bridge is two feet underwater. Henry gets out of the truck and walks closer to get a look. No way across. Off Henry, wheels turning, panic rising... INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - NIGHT Hard rain outside with occasional flashes of lightning accompanied by rumbling THUNDER. Florence, Marlon and Lil May, all rapt, sit around the table listening to Hap read letter from Ronsel.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: “I wish you all were there to see it. Her dress was so glittery it looked like it was made of stars. Even the white GI's couldn't take their eyes off her. But tell Lilly May, even the great Lena Horne hasn't got half the voice she does. And please tell Marlon I tried to save him some snow, but it melted. So I'll be bringing him a glass of water instead. Ha ha." Smiles are exchanged. It’s like Ronsel is right there wit them.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “And please let momma know that I-- BANGING at the door. Florence drops out of her reverie. M BANGING. Hap answers the door-- Henry soaked and desperat

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mist McAllan.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I need Florence. My little girls have taken sick with whooping cough. I can’t get to town because the bridge is washed out. And I remember you saying she was a midwife.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: My wife ain’t a doctor.  38.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I realize that. But my wife...

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: When they start the whooping?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Isabelle’s been sick for a couple days now. Amanda Leigh’s cough started up this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: They still catching.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: She can give you some remedies to take but she can’t go with you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I’1ll pay you.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t be able to come home for three or four days. Who gon’ look after my own family?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Please. My wife is afraid. Florence and Hap consider Henry. Henry’s pride and upbringing won’t allow him to beg any further.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Let me get my things. I’1l meet you outside. Florence moves to Marlon and Lily May and hugs them both.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be good for your father.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT HENRY’S TRUCK - NIGHT Pounding Rain. Henry watches as Florence lifts a flapping chicken out of the coop, shoves it in a burlap sack in on easy swoop. Florence strides gracefully to the truck, doe miss a beat. Henry’s confusion apparent.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Girls gon’ need broth.  39.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: And you all don’t have chickens yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry sluices through the rain, Florence watches him from side of her eyes. *

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I didn’t have the luxury of only loving my own children. My own mother, I remember being blue. Blue from the dark of the morning, when the moon would still be up. She: kissing me and my sister, Us: pretending to be sleep. Us: not yet awake. My mother blue in the twilight, the sun not yet risen. She: going off to work to wake and kiss some other woman’s children in the sunlight. INT. HENRY’S PICK-UP TRUCK (MOVING) - NIGHT Henry drives and Florence rides, both silent. The road is bumpy and the rain makes the visibility minimal.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mother, blue again from the dark of the evening, well after sunset. After we had eaten the cold suppers she had prepared and left for us. After we had gone to bed and tried to stay awake to see her, when she had been late preparing some other woman’s children hot supper. When I was a little girl, how I hated those other children. The ones that never saw my mother blue. How they never ate the cold. I swore that my children would have all of me. Would see me in the daylight. But now I know what my mother must have known. That if something had ever happened to that other woman’s children, that would have been the end of us. Now I know that she left us not out of duty, but out of love. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) Now I know...that love is a kind of survival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Florence darting to the house.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And Laura McAllan? Thought the Delta would turn her into nothing but grudge and bone. I didn’t have the luxury of thinking only on my own family. INT. THE MCALLAN FARM HOUSE - NIGHT — CONTINUOUS Henry and Florence rush in, Laura looks up and glares daggers. Amanda Leigh is bent over a steaming pot of wate Pappy sits off to the side, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Who’s this, Henry? Where’s the doctor?  40.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: This is Florence Jackson. She’s a midwife.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Do you see anybody giving birth here?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The bridge is washed out. I couldn’t get to town. I thought she might be able to help. Isabelle COUGHS and HACKS from the other room, Florence shoulders past Henry toward the sound. Abandons the coupl their bickering.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: These children need a doctor, not some granny with a bag of potions.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The damn bridge is flooded -- what do you want me to do? Isabelle starts gagging. Laura rushes to the girls’ room. INT. THE MCALLAN FARM HOUSE/GIRLS’ ROOM - CONTINUOUS ...-where Florence turns Isabelle onto her side. Yellow P and BILE bubble from the child’s mouth, Florence wipes it away. Laura kneels across from Florence.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: I seen this with my own children. We need to get liquid down ‘em. But first we got to clear some of that phlegm out.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Make ‘em some horehound tea. That was real good, you making the steam for ‘em. We’ll keep after ‘em with it. Mist McAllan, would you kindly please boil more water, suh? Henry nods and moves off.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That tea’ll draw the phlegm right out. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Once they get to breathing better, we'll make ‘em chicken broth and put ground-up willow bark in it for the fever.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I should have taken them to the doctor as soon as they started coughing. If anything happens...

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Your girls are gonna be just fine. God is watching over ‘em and so am I. And neither one of us going nowhere till they feeling better. Laura nods her appreciation. For an instant, they are sim two mothers tending a sick child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candle and lantern light. The rain has stopped and Floren is cutting up onions and carrots. Pappy sits in the corne cigarette smoke curling around him. Florence has her back him but she feels his eyes on her. She ignores it until:

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: I’m thirsty. Run out to the pump and fetch me some water.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: I got to finish this broth for the children.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: That broth can do without you for a few minutes. (off Florence ignoring) Did you hear me, gal? I want some damn water. Laura enters from the girls’ bedroom:

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: There’s drinking water in the pail by the sink. (then to Florence) The girls are finally sleeping. After you finish the broth you should go on home, Florence.  42.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Yes'm, but like I told your husband, that whooping cough is catching. If I went home I could pass it to my own children.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We'll make room for you here.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Ain’t sleeping under the same roof as a nigger.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Florence, why don’t you go check on the girls? Florence moves into the GIRLS’ BEDROOM.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can’t send her home to infect her own family.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How the girls doing?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: They’re asleep. And now your father is proposing we send Florence home.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: She'll infect her own family.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Then she can sleep out in the barn.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: How could you suggest such a thing in this cold?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Niggers need to know their place.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: For the last few hours her place has been by your granddaughters’ bedside. Which is more than I can say for you. She sleeps here. Amanda Leigh starts coughing. Laura goes to her. Pappy glowers.  43. INT. THE MCALLAN FARM HOUSE/GIRLS’ ROOM - DAY The room is dark until Florence opens a shutter and sunli breaks through. Amanda Leigh and Isabelle are sleeping comfortably in their beds. As Florence tidies up, Amanda Leigh's eyes flutter open and squint against the daylight

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA LEIGH
dialogues.text: Momma? Florence checks Amanda Leigh’s forehead for fever and the smiles because it has broken. She checks Isabelle’s she i fine too.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Morning. Glad to see you feeling better. (beat) I’ll go fetch your momma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Florence quickly packs her things, anxious to get h Laura and Henry are in the kitchen area talking quietly. Pappy is sitting by a table, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: ‘Scuse me, Mist McAllan? I’m ready.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We can’t thank you enough for your help, Florence.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. Just keep after ‘em with the tea. They’ll be fine now.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We have some good news for you. (off Florence) We'd like to offer you a job. Working here. For me. I’11 need help with the girls, cooking, cleaning, that sort of thing. Florence flicks a look to Pappy, reeling at the prospect dealing with him every day.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It means extra money for you and your family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura smiles, waiting for Florence to leap at the opportunity. Off Florence, not leaping...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - NIGHT The kids are asleep. Hap and Florence whisper by lantern light.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: How can we say no?

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: We don’t belong to them. We pay rent, work our own crops for us. That's it. They can’t just pick us up, set us down like we tools.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You're the one always talking about saving. How owning our own parcel the only way to get out from under they foot. We’re almost there.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: I don’t want you working for them.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be working for them. I’d be working for us. (beat) I already said yes. Hap pulls away from her. Hap warms.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: (quoting scripture) “For the husband is the head of the wife, even as Christ is the head of the church.”

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: “An excellent wife who can find? She is far more precious than jewels. The heart of her husband trusts in her and he will have no lack of gain...

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: All those Sundays you really are listening, huh?  Florence kisses him, strokes his beard.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: And now you need to listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence watches as Hap inspects their prone, panting MUL Laying on his side, he foams at the mouth, limbs paralyze Hap drops his head, looks up at Florence. PRELAP the soun a GUNSHOT... INT. HAP’S CHURCH - DAY Hap is a bullet across the pulpit. He transmutes despair belief behind his own eyes. He rallies, forces himself to clap and sing. The church falls in with him. Florence tri to sing along but looks exhausted behind her eyes.  47. EXT. HAP’S CHURCH - DAY Hap still in his Sunday clothes high up on a ladder. He hammers a mismatched length of siding into place. Another DEACON patches shingles on the roof. Hap stops, takes in sunset behind him. Marlon sprinting back up the road with building supplies. Hap puffs at the sight of his son.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pride goeth before a fall. But I was just looking at God’s own creation. Is that pride? Is that a sin? Why? Hap’s hammer slips from his grip, he clutches after it, t ladder tumbles sideways. Hap falling in slow motion.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can’t answer my children when they ask me. Hap now paralyzed on the ground, stiff and sputtering lik the mule. Marlon and other Deacons gathering around him. Hap’s eyes wide in surprise. Hap blacks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS: HAP’S FAILED CONVALESCENCE --Florence cleans Hap’s leg, a river of bloody puss runs broken skin. Hap doesn’t cry out. His leg is discolored a misshapen. Florence wraps clean bandages around it -- Hap pushes open his bedroom window, sees FLORENCE and MARLON working the field on their own. Florence coaches t boy along, they work well past dark, invisible except for their bobbing lanterns and the percussion of seed bags bouncing against their legs -- Lilly May changes Hap's bedpan, Hap holds himself up o trembling elbow, keeps his face craned toward the wall. S pools in the corner of his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence and Marlon’s hard labor apparent in symmetrical of furrowed new earth. A RAIN DROP kisses the ground. The another. Another.  48.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The rain came that next day, a big hard rain that packed the fields down tight as wax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence and children quiet against the windows as they w nature undo weeks of work.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nothing we could do set there and watch it and fret for two days until it finally cleared up. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAWN Hap watches his family out the window as they hoist their hoes and water buckets out to the mud-slicked mess to beg again. Lilly Mae in an oversized hat has joined them this time and jogs to keep up. Four lanterns bobbing against c daybreak.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Lingered along, lingered along. Laid in that bed knowing my wife was out doing my work for me. Florence's hands all blistered up and I seen her rubbing her back when she thought I wasn’t looking. Hap picks up a BIRCH BASKET he’s been working on, resumes weaving. The racket of Henry’s tractor crashes the peace.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hap!

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: In here. Henry McAllan appears in the window, inventories the room

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How're you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Better by the day.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I expect you are. Henry lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much longer you gonna be laid up?

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Doc Turpin said six weeks, it’s been four already. I bet I’1l be out there by Monday.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Welp. I don’t think you gon’ have enough time to get everything in the ground. You're skinning it close.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Florence and the boys are working double time sir. Plus you know fields gotta be rebroke because of that rain.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Can’t control the rain. (beat) But y’all ought be well into planting by now and you haven't even gotten your fields laid by. I can’t afford to wait any longer, you're a farmer you understand that.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: As it stands, it’1l be the end of the week ‘fore they even start fertilizing. Now if they had a mule, they’d be done in no time.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: We lost our mule to lockjaw sir. Florence and the boys are--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You’re gonna have to rent one of my mules. You’ll go back on half shares to pay it off. The verdict sticks in Hap’s throat. Henry already ambling back to his tractor.  50.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Send one a your boys to come fetch that mule after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Yessir. The blare of Henry’s tractor engine. Hap throws off the b covers. Drenched in sweat, he snatches down a pair of workpants. He lifts his bad leg into the trouser hole and shimmies his pants over his waist. He shifts his weight o his good leg and levers himself upright on one leg. He ta a fortifying breath, slowly eases his bad foot to the gro

dialogues.speaker: AGH
dialogues.text: A horrible CRUNCHING sound as Hap falls in a heap to the floor. Hap lets a SOB escape for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What do you mean Florence isn’t coming back?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s only till July, she’s got to get that crop in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Where’s Hap?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: His leg is broke. I told you that.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No you didn’t. Henry? I need help with the girls. Can’t you lend them a mule?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No we can’t lend them a mule, it’s just like with the Atwoods if they can’t get the work done on time, the have to rent one of ours and pay us half of the crop for it. Tough for them, good for us. Are you for us?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hap hurt himself working for us--  51.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Hap hurt himself working for Hap!! Laura recoils, Henry catches himself.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Farming is a business Laura. And like any business it carries risks.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I just think--

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I sank everything into this farm. Everything. We need to make some money this year. If we don’t, our family’s in trouble. Now. Do you understand that? Laura holds her tongue, lifts her chin .

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He kept the money in a strongbox under the floorboards of our bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Eight. Thirty. Sixty Two. The date the Confederate forces crushed the Union Army in the Battle of Richmond. Laura's fingers spin the dial and open the box. A stack o wrinkled cash.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t think he knew that I knew the combination.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - EVENING

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR PEARLMAN
dialogues.text: Hello Mrs. Jackson? Florence surprised at the unaccustomed respect. The thick German accent.  52.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR PEARLMAN
dialogues.text: I’m Doctor Pearlman. I’m here to treat your husband.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Oh... Thank you. Florence steps aside, waves the doctor in. Florence spots Laura idling in the truck. Laura waves from the driver's seat. Florence waves back as she pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you’da asked me before then, I’'da told you all white folks was the same.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR PEARLMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Whoever did this is not a doctor. Florence follows the Doctor’s voice into the bedroom, lin in the doorway. DOCTOR PEARLMAN (CONT’D) It’s badly infected and I’m going to have to re-set the bone. Hap motions for a bottle of WHISKEY. Florence reaches for Doctor Pearlman unearths an ANESTHETIC MASK, and a vial o CHLOROFORM. DOCTOR PEARLMAN (CONT’D) No, no that won’t be necessary, of course I’m going to administer an anesthetic. Hap and Florence embarrassed. Doctor Pearlman favors Flor with a smile. DOCTOR PEARLMAN (CONT’D) But a little whiskey never hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura lying on her back, her gown below her knees  53.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Henry stayed mad at me. And he showed it by ignoring me in our bed. Henry clomps in, pretends not to see her. Laura hoists he gown up to her thighs.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hadn't always enjoyed Henry's lovemaking, but it made me feel like a true wife. He liked to do it at night with one candle. That was his signal, the rasp of match against the striker. Henry blows out the candle. Gives her his back. Laura caresses Henry’s back. He ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I never thought of refusing him. How could he refuse me? No it wasn’t fulfilling. But it was at least a kind of sweet intimacy. Laura reaches over, gropes between Henry’s legs. Henry pi her hand up, places it back on her side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I never realized how much I needed that until he turned away from me. INT. A MODEST GERMAN HOUSE - BEDROOM — DAY Sunlight fills the room where Ronsel and Resl sleep peacefully entwined. We notice a delicate gold necklace w a_crucifix hanging from Resl’s neck. A few quiet beats, t a cacophony of HORN HONKS and JEEP ENGINES crescendos. Ronsel wakes quickly but Resl snoozes on. Then, outside, hears HOOTS and HOLLERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronsel extracts himself from Resl’s sleepy embrace and mo to the window. There he sees a procession of American soldiers hanging off jeeps and trucks, waving American fl

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIERS OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: War's over! Hitler’s dead! The war’s over! Ronsel watches them wondering if it’s true. Resl joins hi at the window as the impromptu victory parade rolls by.  54. They look at each other, both knowing what it means: he’s going home soon. A melancholy embrace. Ronsel closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BUS —- DAY As Ronsel is suddenly woken up by the CONDUCTOR (White, 4 who moves down the aisle from the loose White section to over-packed Colored section.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Tupelo! Next stop! Tupelo! Ronsel is in his dress uniform, adorned with medals. He shakes off his sleep, looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Home again, home again. Jiggety - jig. Coon, spade, darky, nigger. Went off to fight for my country and came back to find it hadn’t changed a bit. Ronsel reaches into his pocket and pulls out Resl’s gold necklace and crucifix - a keepsake. Ronsel notices a LITT BOY staring at him. Ronsel winks. The Little Boy salutes. Ronsel returns the salute.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: EXT. TRICKLEBANK’S GENERAL STORE - DAY Ronsel hops off the bus, pack slung, medals twinkling. He takes his time surveying the stark town strip, a few loitering WHITE TOWNSMEN eye him as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. TRICKLEBANK’S GENERAL STORE - CONTINUOUS Ronsel enters and finds Laura chatting with store owner, TRICKLEBANK (Caucasian, female, 30's). Rose is back-count tough and wears a bandana to pull back her hair.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Howdy, Miz Tricklebank.

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
