dialogues.text: Ronsel, is that you?  54a.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am, last time I looked.  55.

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
dialogues.text: Well, I declare. Aren’t you grown up. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Can’t complain. How you been?

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
dialogues.text: Getting along fine. You seen your folks yet? As Ronsel grabs canned goods, sugar, and candy:

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: No, I just got in. I wanted to stop and buy a few things for ‘em first.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hello, Ronsel. I’m Mrs. McAllan. Your parents work on our farm.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: How do, ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Do Hap and Florence know you’re coming home?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: No, I wanted to surprise ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Your mother talks about you all the time. I know they’1l be mighty glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Likewise.

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
dialogues.text: (re: Ronsel’s purchases) That everything?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
dialogues.text: Sugar and candy too?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Sugar’s for my momma. Candy’s for Marlon and Lilly May. Figured I'd spoil ‘ema little. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiling re: his stripes) Sergeant’s pay.

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
dialogues.text: I’m sure they'll appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: My brother served in the Pacific. And my husband’s brother was a bomber pilot. Both of them fine, thank God. Nice to see you boys finally coming home.

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
dialogues.text: Comes to four dollars even. As Rose puts Ronsel’s things into a sack, Orris Stokes en the store. He’s so big he takes up the entire doorway.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Well looky what we got here. A jig in a uniform. Ronsel ignores the comment and pays Rose:

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miz Tricklebank.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Just then Henry and Pappy enter the store with ANOTHER MA Ronsel grabs his things and tries to step around Stokes s can exit. But Stokes moves in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Where you think you’re going, boy?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Beg pardon, suh. Just trying to get home to see my folks.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Not that way you ain’t.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Henry, this is Hap and Florence's son, Ronsel. He just returned from overseas.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Well, that explains why you’re trying to leave by the front door. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must be confused as to your whereabouts.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: I ain’t confused at all, suh.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Oh, I think you are, boy. I don’t know what they let you do over there, but you’re in Mississippi now, nigger. You use the back door.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Go on now. We don’t want any trouble. Go on. Fists clench as the air thickens with hostility. Ronsel i anchored where he stands, head high and defiant as he squarely meets the gaze of each man in the room. Laura's eyes plead with him to just go. Then Ronsel looks to Papp

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: You know, suh, you’re right. We didn’t go in the back over there. General Patton put us right up on the front lines. Yessuh, he took us when nobody else thought we were worth a damn. And you know we did? We kicked the hell outta Hitler and them Jerries. All while every one of you was back here safe and sound at home. No need to thank me. (then) Miz Tricklebank. Miz McAllan. The white men are agape as Ronsel grabs his things and strides out the back door. Angles toward the long dusty r out of town. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bless us, oh Lord, and these thy gifts which we are about to receive from thy bounty through Christ our Lord and savior. Hap, Florence, Marlon, Ruel and Lilly May, all with their eyes closed, mid-prayer:  58.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And, Lord, thank you for the sun you been sending to make the cotton grow and for the health of all here present. And, Lord Jesus, please watch over my boy, Ronsel, wherever in creation he may be.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Amen. Heads snap to the doorway where Ronsel is standing. The Jacksons are collectively frozen.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, ain’t nobody gonna offer me some supper?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: Ronsel! And Lilly May is up like a flash and in Ronsel’s arms. Florence is immediately driven to tears as she wraps her around Ronsel and covers him with kisses.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: My baby...

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Hi, momma.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: So grown.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: Handsome too. Marlon works his way in and hugs Ronsel tightly.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Marlon here’s catching up with me! How tall are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: Wha’d you get all them medals for?

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: How was the trip home?

dialogues.speaker: MARLON FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You get ‘em for killing Why didn’t you write to tell Germans? us you was coming?  59.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Quit fussing over him now and let him say hello to his father. They part so Hap can take a look at Ronsel. Then Ronsel rushes up and hugs him. Hap holds his son, tears welling.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I knew you’d come. I prayed for it. EXT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - NIGHT It’s a warm night and a blanket of stars covers the sky. Cigarette smoke curls up into it and we find Ronsel on th porch of the shack, smoking as he stares at the heavens. reacts when Hap and Florence come out.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: I’ve never known you to smoke, son.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: A lot’s changed.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You sure you get enough to eat?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: I’m stuffed. Used to dream about them biscuits, Momma.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: I dreamt about you too.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: What did you see? Florence shakes her head and shivers at the thought. Then

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You back with us now. Safe and sound.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Be nice to have another pair of hands. With you home we might can make up what we lost after my accident. Payoff the lien, get a new contract, go back to being tenants next year--

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Maybe he got plans of his own, Hap. Let him find his own mind.  60.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Yeah. I mean, of course. I'll stay awhile. It’1ll give me time to figure things out. Put the war behind me. Hap is excited by the prospect, leans against the post hi crutches forgotten. But Ronsel is far away and is only feigning enthusiasm. HEADLIGHTS of a truck coming down th road. The truck pulls into the yard and Henry gets out.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: What’s he want now? Ronsel stiffens. Hap and Florence trade a look as Henry strides up to the porch.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Evening, Hap. Florence.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Mist McAllan. This is our son, Ronsel, I told you about.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We've met. (then) I’d better speak to you alone, Hap.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: I ain’t a child. Sir. You got something to say to my father, you can say it to me too.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: All right then. You’re asking for a heap of trouble by acting like you did earlier at Tricklebank’s. And I know you don’t want trouble, least of all for your family here.

dialogues.speaker: HAP FLORENCE
dialogues.text: What’d you do? He couldn’ta done anything.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Just tried to walk out the door is all.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The front door. And when my father corrected him he made a fine speech. Put us all in our place, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Is that true? (off Ronsel’s nod) Then I reckon you best apologize. Henry waits and Ronsel glares. But Ronsel knows he has no choice and he forces the words out:

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: I’m mighty sorry, Mr. McAllan.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: My father’1l wanna hear it too.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Ronsel will pay him a visit after church tomorrow. Won’t you, son?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Hap needles Ronsel out the side of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Good. We'll be expecting you, boy. Henry strolls back to his truck and pulls off. Hap sees t frustration in Ronsel’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: No point in fighting ‘em. They just gon’ win every time.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Not used to walking away from fights, daddy. Not anymore. Ronsel eases past his father. Florence catches Ronsel’s h at the door, squeezes. Ronsel kisses his mother’s hand, p it as he moves off. Hap and Florence exchange wordless worries in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: X1000/A9BXT JACKSON CABIN
dialogues.text: Ronsel & Florence lounge in their separate thoughts. Take the sleeping silence. Ronsel materializes a Hershey Bar a lays it on her knee.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: For you.  61A. Florence stunned from her day dream.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Oh. I -- no. This is so much. Your brothers and sister will love this. I'll save it -- Florence moves to take the bar in her apron. Ronsel puts hands on hers.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: No. It's for you.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Oh baby, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Go head. I'ma watch you. Florence giggles, backs in pampering. She ventures one mo square, pleasure washes over her face. Florence holds Ronsel's gaze stuffs down overflowing emotions.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: (Beat) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: I love you Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouting from the barn. It’s Henry arguing with Carl Atwo Their discussion moves towards the porch:  62.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t give a damn! If you can’t do your job, I can’t keep you on. That’s how it works.

dialogues.speaker: ATWOOD
dialogues.text: Henry, please, I got Vera and the girls and one on the way -- we don’t got anyplace else to go.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That’s not my problem, Carl. And I got kids too. But I’m runnin’ a farm here, not a charity.

dialogues.speaker: ATWOOD
dialogues.text: Please, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'll give you to the end of the week. And then I want you gone. Henry walks away. As he moves past Laura and into the hou Carl stands there, shell-shocked. Then eventually, he mov off down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura reading in a chair, rocking herself unconsciously. Atwood waddling up the porch steps--pregnant belly, fresh black eye and split lip.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: Howdy Miz McAllan! Vera like a child, pressed against the screen door. Laura lowers her book, affixes pleasantness to her face.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hello. Miss--

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: Vera. You can call me Vera.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hello Vera.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: This here is my youngest, Alma. Vera’s skinny daughter ALMA, recessive of chin and dull o eye lifts her gaze to Laura’s.  63.

dialogues.speaker: VERA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We needa talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vera crossing her dirty bare feet on Laura’s rug. Laura t not to notice. Her daughter Alma in the window picking at ends of her hair.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: You cain’t put us off.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: We ain’t got nowhere to go if you put us off. Nobody’1l hire us this late in the season.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s not up to me Vera, it’s up to my husband. Vera rubs her pregnant belly.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: I’m asking you to keep us on.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m telling you, it’s not my decision.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: And if it was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura hums as she churns butter on the porch while Henry reads the paper and Pappy smokes. Laura’s churning is especially tense and Henry notices:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Alright then, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You got something on your mind. I can tell. (off Laura) You sing when you're happy. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And hum when you’re not. C’mon now, out with it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Vera Atwood is eight and a half months pregnant. Where would they go? How would they survive?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Ain’t this touching? Saint Laura, protector of women and children.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Atwood is a lazy, stupid drunk. He’s lucky I’ve kept him this long.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Then make him work on half shares like Hap and his family.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why would I go through all that when I can just hire a new tenant?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Because you are a Christian.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: The Lord ain’t the one putting food on our table.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Didn’t you tell me most farmers around here can’t find enough help to make a crop? (beat) Call it a business decision. For the good of the farm. Laura has a point.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I’ll have a word with Carl tomorrow morning. Just a word. Laura rewards him with the tiniest smile, softens her churning. Henry basks in her quiet favor.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Next she'll be telling you what to plant.  65. EXT. MCALLAN FARM HOUSE -— MORNING Laura’s hands red, raw, and forgotten between her knees. washboard leans in a still steaming bucket of gray water. Laura stares at a dead mouse curled on the bottom step.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Violence is part and parcel of country life. You're forever being assailed by dead things. Amanda Leigh accidentally bumps a pair of trousers off th clothesline. Amanda Leigh jumps back from the muddy heap, braces for her mother’s censure. Laura just blinks. Amand Leigh slings the pants back onto the line and scurries aw

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dead mice, dead rabbits, dead possums, dead birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POSSUM CORPSE languishes beneath a tree. Ants march in out of its pink mouth.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You find them in the yard. You smell them rotting under the house. EXT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY A sharp flick of the wrist, Florence SNAPS a chicken’s ne The body flops and unspirals itself as she runs a boning knife across the jugular, spills hot blood onto the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then there are the creatures you kill for food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dirty CHILDREN straddle and climb the rickety porch raili Vera Atwood nudges tight brown fur backward over limp squirrel haunches.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Chickens, hogs, deer, frogs, squirrels. Pluck, skin, disembowel, debone, fry. Vera wipes her nose on her shoulder, wedges the too-dull pocketknife deeper under the skin.  66.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Eat. Start again. Kill. Laura runs a pipe cleaner down the barrel of a HUNTING RI

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I learned how to stitch up a bleeding wound, load and fire a shotgun, reach into the womb of heaving sow to deliver a breech piglet. My hands did these things. Laura snaps the barrel into place.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I was never easy in my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura gnawing at the balls of her hands. Thick yellow callouses peel off between her teeth. She chews them thoughtfully. Stares out the window entranced.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA LEIGH
dialogues.text: Momma, somebody’s coming! A handsome soldier in aviator sunglasses carrying a suitc Laura looks and realizes: AMANDA LEIGH (CONT’D) Uncle Jamie!! Laura shoots to her feet, smooths her hands against her apron.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jamie?! Henry whoops and bolts off the porch, limp and all. Laura hangs back in the doorway. She straightens her dress and runs her fingers through her hair. She sights her dirty fingernails, clasps her hands behind her back. Henry rocks Jamie in a tight embrace. They separate, look each other. Grab each other again.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You look good, brother.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You look like hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don’t sugarcoat it now. 67. Laura edges closer with Amanda Leigh and Isabelle, she ho out her hands for a squeeze. Jamie smiles, scoops her int hug instead.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Laura. Sweet sister-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Welcome home, Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: How are you liking it here in Henry’s version of paradise? Laura starts to answer but is spared from having to lie b

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You’d think a son would see fit to greet his own father.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Dearest Pappy. I’d forgotten how much I missed you. Said with a cut of sarcasm as Jamie shakes Pappy’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Jamie re: Pappy) He’s missed you too. He won't admit it but he has.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I bet. And he probably quit smoking and joined the NAACP too. Laura laughs and Jamie winks at her. Pappy doesn’t apprec the joke. Then Jamie smiles at Amanda Leigh and Isabelle.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well hello little ones. Give your uncle Jamie a hug. The girls run and jump into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jitter of Jamie’s hand as he cradles a lit cigarette. pours a drink and finishes in a single draught. Pappy tak note, doesn’t hide his disdain. Henry pretends not to see  68.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: So what's it like being a big hero?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Don’t give me that. Army wrote me about your fancy medals. Said they was the highest honors an airman could receive.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I was lucky. Lotta guys weren't.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Bet you got plenty of tail out of it too.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Jamie’s never needed medals to get girls.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Damn right. Takes after me that way. Your momma was the prettiest girl in Greenville. And I had ‘em all sniffing after me. Pappy smiles with his yellow teeth. Jamie shifts in his chair and lights one cigarette with another.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One thing’s for sure. You must’a killed a whole lotta Krauts to get all them medals. (beat) Well, how many’d you take out?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Take a guess.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Why’s it matter?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: A man ought to know how many men he’s killed.  69. Henry returns with the bottle and a glass. Jamie quickly uncorks it and pours heavily. He gulps it down and refill Henry is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I can tell you this. (beat) It was more than one.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Aw, shit. Pappy’s eyes narrow and he seethes for a beat,

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Well, at least I looked my one in the eye before I shot him. Not like dropping bombs from a mile up in the air. Jamie throws back his drink and pours another. uncomfortable silence until Henry interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well, good time to hit the hay. Got an early day tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I'll just finish my drink. then smirks: Then there is Pappy absorbs this, grabs a lantern and shuffles out. Jam slugs back his whiskey. His eyes flick back to the bottle Henry grabs it and moves it out of range.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What you need is a good night’s sleep. Laura made a bed up for you. Jamie stands and Henry gives him a hug.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Welcome home, little brother. (beat) Now, go on, get some sleep. Henry starts to move off.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Actually it was more like four.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What?  70.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Miles up in the air. The altitude we dropped bombs from.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How can you even see anything from that high up?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised. Roads, cities, factories. Just not people. From twenty thousand feet they’re not even ants. (beat) Pappy’s right. A man ought to know. Jamie is haunted. Henry is concerned. INT. TRICKLEBANK’'S GENERAL STORE - DAY Rose Tricklebank takes her time bagging groceries for Jam Jamie is polite, but curt as his eyes are on his freshly purchased bottle of bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
dialogues.text: How long you been back from overseas now?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Coupl’a weeks.

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
dialogues.text: And how’re you liking Marietta?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Lovely little town. Just lovely. Tricklebank moves to bag the bourbon, but Jamie intervene

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, I got that one. Let’s just put that right here. Jamie puts the bottle in a convenient spot, hurriedly sho in the remaining provisions.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There we go. Much obliged, Miz Tricklebank. You have yourself a wonderful day. Jamie smiles, grabs his stuff and heads out.  71.

dialogues.speaker: TRICKLEBANK
dialogues.text: Take care, now. Come back soon. EXT. TRICKLEBANK’S GENERAL STORE - DAY - CONTINUOUS Jamie hustles past a handful of WHITE TOWNSMEN on the por of the store. Among them is Orris Stokes. A passing car BACKFIRES. Jamie hits the ground and covers his head. Groceries spill everywhere. The townsmen murmur and stare

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s alright. It was just a car. A helping hand extended, Jamie follows it up to Ronsel.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Backfired. Must have a stuck intake valve. Jamie looks up at the porch and sees mean eyes staring fr underneath hat brims. He ignores Ronsel’s hand, gets up a retrieves his groceries. Ronsel helps. But when Jamie gra the bourbon his hand shakes so badly he drops it. Thankfu it doesn’t break.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Dammit.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: They say it stops eventually. Ronsel holds out his own hand and it shakes like Jamie's. They trade a look and despite being from different worlds there’s an instant kinship.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You’re Ronsel, Hap’s boy. (off Ronsel’s nod) Jamie McAllan. Henry’s brother. Jamie offers a hand shake. Ronsel is surprised by the sho of respect, but he obliges.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You walk here?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I‘1l give you a lift. (off Ronsel’s reluctance) C'mon.  72.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Jamie and Ronsel move to the truck where Ronsel hops in t truck bed and Jamie hops in the driver’s side. Both of th are aware of the men still watching from the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie steals looks at Ronsel through the back window, squ with guilt. Memories of the B25 echo in his ears. Ronsel oblivious to it, chasing his daydreams flitting across th landscape. Jamie pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Come on up front.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: I’m doing just fine back here.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Get in soldier! That’s an order! A beat, then the truck rocks as Ronsel hops off and gets the passenger side.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: How do you know you outranked me?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I was a captain.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: We had Negro captains. I served under plenty.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (shrugging) You obeyed my order. Bet you were a sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: 761st tank battalion. “Come Out Fighting”! Spearheaded for Patton. You?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I flew B-25's. Jamie reaches into the grocery bag between them and takes the bourbon bottle. He uncorks it then takes a long, much needed swig and drives on.  73.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, sergeant, how do you like being back here in the Delta? Ronsel doesn’t answer, he just looks away.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too. (beat) Heard you and my Pappy had words.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: (stiffening) I apologized for that. Then to Ronsel’s surprise, Jamie toasts with the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He’s a disagreeable sonovabitch. I’m sure he had it coming. (offering the bourbon) Here’s to you.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You always this stubborn? Or is it just around white people trying to be nice? Ronsel eyes Jamie, then he grabs the bottle, takes a quic sip and tries to hand it back.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What kind of NCO are you? Then Ronsel takes a big swig. So big it makes him choke a spill a little. Jamie laughs:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t waste it now. That’s my medicine. I need every drop. Ronsel admits a slight grin as he recovers and hands the bottle back. Jamie takes a pull, then:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, you tanker boys ever piss in your helmets?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Plenty of times.  74.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We had relief tubes up in the cockpit but sometimes it was easier just to use our flak helmets. And at twenty thousand feet? That piss freezes solid in less than minute.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: It’s that cold up there?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I’m talking twenty, thirty below zero. And one time we were on this long haul and I went in my helmet and forgot all about it. Then when we got close to the target, I put the helmet back on. And we're doing our bombing run, dodging enemy flak and suddenly I feel something running down my face. They both laugh as Jamie passes the bottle back to Ronsel

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I smelled like a damn latrine.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: You must’a caught hell back at the officer's club.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: My buddies never let me hear the end of it. (beat) The ones that made it back anyway.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Lost some friends myself. They drive on in silence. INT. HENRY’S PICK-UP TRUCK - LATER Jamie and Ronsel pull up and stop at the Jackson's shack.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Thanks for the ride.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome.  75. EXT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN —- DAY - SIMULATANEOUS Hap, having heard truck, comes out of the shack. Jamie ro the window down and smiles drunkenly.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Everything alright Mist Jamie?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Everything's fine. I just gave Ronsel here a lift from town. Ronsel rounds the truck, makes his way up the porch stair

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll be heading into town again next Saturday afternoon. I’11 stop by, see if you want a ride.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: That'd be fine.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (a nod) Hap. Then Jamie pulls out and weaves off down the road. Off Ha worried, as he looks at Ronsel...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MCALLAN FARM OUTHOUSE- DAY
dialogues.text: Laura sloshes through ankle deep mud, trudges to the lean outhouse. Laura opens the door to the BUZZING of flies. It’s a hot and the smell in here is oppressive. Breathing though her mouth, she lifts her skirt, squats and pees. She looks do at the mud caked onto her boots and the hem of her dress. SERIES OF SHOTS: LAURA’S TORTUOUS BATHING RITUAL

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Saturday was my favorite day of the week. --LAURA pumping water in the yard, she hauls sloshing buc to the stove

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was the only day I felt truly clean. --LAURA hauling steaming water to a ZINC TUB in the yard, bathes her muddy DAUGHTERS. The water turns brown.  76. --The girls clean-washed and napping on the porch. LAURA lowers herself into their cloudy lukewarm leftovers. Laur cups water over herself, squats in the fleeting privacy o flapping sheet. PAPPY happens by, averts his eyes a littl too slowly.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The rest of the time, we stank. --Laura dumps the dirty water. Henry pecks her on the che as he drags into the yard covered in mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Laura looks at her expanding belly in a mirror. She turns profile and sighs with a grin. A beat, then Henry enters. Laura looks at him and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What? (off Laura) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, honey... Oh Lord! (hugging and kissing her) Woo!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Shhh, you’1l wake the girls. Henry hugs her again and they are overjoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura, with bleary eyes and a baby bump, shuffles into th room where Florence works in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Near to ten o’clock, Ms. Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Good heavens.  77.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Yes'm, you definitely carrying a boy. Ronsel and Marlon both, couldn’t wake me for nothing. (beat) Something for you on the table. Laura notices a pretty bunch of lavender wrapped up in a bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Where are these from? Then Laura notices a note next to the flowers. “Congratulations. Love, Jamie” Laura closes her eyes and draws in the scent of the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He remembered I like lavender. How sweet. Then suddenly, she has to pee like a pregnant lady.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ooh, excuse me. Nature calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Laura hustles to the privy. Then she enters to find bouquets of lavender everywhere - in cans on the floor, i bunches nailed to the wall and hanging from the ceiling. Laura chuckles and smiles wide then takes a whiff. Not ba it’s working. Then she lifts her skirt, squats and pees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie and Ronsel stumble from the truck to the dilapidate saw mill. Ronsel hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: C'mon, now, we’re clear of town, nobody’s out here. (with a bourbon bottle) Don’t make me drink alone. I will if I have to. Ronsel prys at a loose board.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Hope this damn thing don’t fall down on us.  78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie and Ronsel shimmy in through a ragged gap. It’s old decrepit and laden with cobwebs. Shafts of sunlight jut i through the wooden slats.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Used to come here when I was a boy. Whenever I needed to be alone and think.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Well I love what you’ve done with the place. Jamie offers Ronsel a smoke. Ronsel accepts and Jamie lig his own then tosses Ronsel the lighter. Ronsel lights up tosses the lighter back.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Why you treating me so nice?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Because you look like you could use it.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Jamie drags on his smoke and measures Ronsel with a drunk eye. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We were somewhere over Austria and we made contact with a swarm of Messerschmitts. They were everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s bumpy as Jamie holds the plane on course. Suddenly bullets rip through the cockpit and the co-pilot gets shredded. Blood splatters on Jamie and on the “LADY LUCK” pin-up girl. Jamie is horrified and we hear his VOICE OVE

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Took out my tail gunner, side gunner...my co-pilot. Made a deal with God right there. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Swore if he saved me I was gonna do something right. I didn’t know what, but I promised anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Next thing you know, whole bunch of P-38's show up. Just like the goddamn cavalry. They knocked those Germans right outta the sky. I swear they were angels sent by the Lord himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie holds the plane on it’s shaky course. Then he looks out to his left and sees a U.S. fighter plane come close.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Those P-38’s, their tails were painted red. And one of ‘em, he buzzed me after the fight. When I looked over I thought I was seeing things. But that fighter pilot? He was colored. The fighter pilot looks at Jamie and salutes. Jamie retur the favor. Then the fighter plane rolls and peels off.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Then he saluted me. And I saluted back. (beat) Men who died that day... They were fathers. Husbands. Good men. Lot better than me. Jamie steeps in his survivor guilt. Ronsel hands him the bottle and he drinks. They trade a look, a bond forming.  80.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As usual, when anything bad happened, Henry was away.He And Pappy had gone to see about some hogs, so I was alone with the girls. Amanda Leigh and Isabelle making mudpies by the water pum Laura , PREGNANT, mending one of Henry’s shirts. Vera Atw barefoot with a FILLETING KNIFE, unlatches the fence, saunters into the yard. Her sweaty dress clinging to her, smile incongruous.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: You need to take me to town. I’m gon’ kill Carl. Laura clocks Vera’s knife. Checks the girls who are playi on, oblivious. Laura keep panic out of her voice.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Come here Vera, come sit down and tell me what’s--

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: I don’t have time to sit down. He’s with her now. He’s started in on Alma, just like he did with Renie. Amanda Leigh looking scared, she takes her sister’s hand. Laura keeps panic out of her voice.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Amanda Leigh take your sister into the house. Vera directs her wild gaze on them, her knife winks in th light.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on around through the back. Go. Vera rocking back and forth on the heels of her feet now. knife swinging at her side.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Vera-— Vera levels the point of the knife at Laura’s neck.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: You got to take me to town now.  81.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Vera honestly, I--I don’t have the keys.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: I seen you driving before. Laura grasps at a lie.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And I got in trouble for it. Vera blinking, coming back to herself.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My husband took the keys away. Vera buries her face in her hands, lets out a feral howl. Laura hesitates, reaches for her. Vera steps backward out her grasp. Wanders out of the yard and back down the stre like a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They found Carl’s body lying in the road halfway to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl Atwood’s twisted body, dirt blowing across his face. Just another dead thing.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Vera had stabbed him seventeen times then gone on to Marietta and turned herself in to Sheriff Thacker. MEN heft the Carl’s corpse into a truckbed.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Florence said she’d seen her walking down Main Street, covered in blood. She said it looked like she'd bathed in it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) But I didn’t find those details until later. I was too lost in my own misery.  82. Laura stooped, rushing through her house. She draws her bloodied hand from between her legs. Doubles over on the

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA LEIGH
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, momma? She grunts and writhes, her hands pressed to her belly. AMANDA LEIGH (CONT’D) Momma?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I need you to be a big girl and go fetch Florence from her house. Do you remember how to get there? Amanda Leigh nods tightly. Another cramp hits and it hurt

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go. Run as fast as you can. Amanda Leigh takes off and Laura goes to the ground. A growing blood stain forms around her crotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura lays in the bed alone staring at the ceiling. Her expression is stoic and empty. She does not react when Florence enters with food and drink.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: How you feeling, Ms. McAllan? (off Laura’s silence) Brought some tea to help with the cramps.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Florence. For everything.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You know, I understand how you feeling right now, Ms. McAllan. Lost one of my babies once too. Samuel. They trade a look, two women bound by the same tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Might make you feel better to get out of this room.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Maybe tomorrow.  83. Florence lingers sits next to her. Then, after several beats, Laura’s face twists in sorrow and she weeps. Flore holds her, lets the sobs ring out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura sits at the edge of the bed staring at the wall. Th Henry enters. He approaches and puts a hand on her should Laura lets it rest there for a beat, then she gently shru it off. Henry is concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura lays in bed, curled up and depressed. She reacts wh Amanda Leigh and Isabelle enter with wildflowers.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA LEIGH
dialogues.text: We brought you flowers, momma.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thank you, sweetheart. Then Isabelle holds up a molted rattlesnake skin.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: This is for you, momma. We found it in the yard. Laura is repulsed but she feigns delight.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh my, that’s wonderful darling. I'll treasure it. (then) Go on back outside now and play. The girls scamper out and, with two fingers, Laura puts t snake skin far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura lays there, catatonic. We hold on her stillness for beat. Then the silence is broken by HAMMERING. Laura trie to ignore it, but it’s loud and incessant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie hoists Amanda Leigh high over a new wooden stall. There’s a rope attached to a bucket and pulley contraptio mounted up top.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Easy now.  84. Amanda Leigh drops lavender bunches into the bucket of wa

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Momma look! Uncle Jamie’s building a shower!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (to the girls re: Laura) I thought y’all were supposed to keep a look out and tell me if she was coming. (then to Laura) Surprise! Thought you might like a little privacy every now and then. Well, what do you think? Laura stares at it, truly touched by the gesture.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I think it’s marvelous. Thank you. Laura hugs Jamie. It feels good and she sinks into him. A there’s a pin prick of light in the dark tunnel of her depression.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What’s this? Jamie and Laura quickly break the hug when Henry walks up

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Your brother built us a shower.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You don’t say. Henry checks out the handy work and Laura and Jamie trade quick glance. EXT. THE MCALLAN FARM —- SHOWER - SUNSET Laura enters with a towel. The deep thrum of insects and frogs mingles with the distant sound of Amanda Leigh practicing scales on the piano in the house. As Laura gets undressed she looks up and notices large cl stained with hues of pink and gold from the setting sun. She pulls the rope and the bucket tilts and pours water i another bucket punctured with holes which creates a showe effect. Then she releases the rope and stops the water fl Jamie was thoughtful enough to put in a soap dish. In it a purple bar of soap. Laura puts the soap to her nose and draws in the scent. Lavender. She smiles and lathers up.  85. Then she pulls the rope all the way and the entire bucket starts pouring. The water is warm and it feels wonderful. It’s been so long since she had a shower. She rinses and feels so good it’s almost sensual. EXT. THE MCALLAN FARM — DAY Henry drives his tractor through thick mud. The crops hav grown-in but the field is flooded and in bad shape. Then tractor lurches and gets stuck. Henry puts it in reverse the tires just spin and dig deeper. Henry puts it in driv and tries the other direction. To no avail.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dammit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still on one crutch, Hap works the wet, overgrown field. mud makes the hard work even harder. He loses his footing and falls. He gets up, more covered in mud than he was before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly May and Marlon perched on barbed wire fence posts gunning down imaginary enemies. Lilly May wears Ronsel’s helmet, Marlon wears Ronsel’s boots.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: BANG BANG! You dead Nazi cracka, you dead! Marlon oversteers his “tank”.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: GRRRRRR! Domp, domp domp domp. We runnin’ ‘em over! Watch your right gunner! Lilly May swivels her imaginary gun over to the right. Ju then a truck full of WHITE SHARECROPPERS rolls by. Lilly lowers her “gun”. A man tosses a soda bottle in their yar The truck rattles past.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: (whispers ) Bang. You dead. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY Florence mends socks as she looks through a window watchi Ronsel sit against a tree smoking a cigarette. He’s got a thousand yard stare as he mindlessly drags and exhales.  86. Henry’s truck pulls up, Jamie behind the wheel. Ronsel ho into the passenger side. Florence doesn’t like what she sees. Then the truck pulls out and Florence watches it go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence leaning against the porch post, gazing into the distance. Hap hobbles out on his still-splinted leg. He l his crutches against the house, puts his arms around her, inhales her neck. Florence cradles his head.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: You ain't tired?

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: We gotta let him go.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: We're not holding him.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: We are. He’s staying for us.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Maybe he wants to stay. It’s not always gonna be like this. Soon as I’m healed we’ll move outta here. We'll be okay. He’1ll be okay once he has his own place-- Florence drops her head. Hap spins her around to him, pul her into a clumsy one-legged two step. Hap hums some brok tune. Florence melts onto him.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember that?

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You not supposed to be up on this broke leg, Hawthorne Jackson. You never let it heal, you never gon’ walk.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Why walk if I can’t dance? Hap and Florence swaying, hanging in each other’s eyes, grasping for exhausted joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie lights a cigarette and Ronsel sips from the bottle. They're both drunk. It’s hot in here and the sunlit smoke hangs on the humid air.  87.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: The silver star? Damn.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be impressed. I got it for being stupid.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I almost drowned in a flood when I was a kid. Since then, baths, swimming pools, any kind of water I hate it. And this one mission I changed course so we wouldn’t be over the water so long. And, as luck would have it, we ran smack dab into some enemy flak. A lot of it. But I managed to hit the target and bring us all back.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: You so scared of water you’d rather get shot at than fly over it?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Damnedest thing, ain’t it? They share a laugh and a drink, then:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ever miss it sometimes? Being over there? I don’t mean getting shot at, but... I actually miss it.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Me too. Over there I was a Liberator. Had folks lined up on the street cheering and throwing flowers. Back here, I’m just another nigger pushing a plow.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Miss some of the guys too.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Think about ‘em every day.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Seeing different parts of the world. (smiling) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Italian girls. English girls. Ronsel leaks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: It was different over there.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (beat) You ever been with a white girl?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: A few.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Well I’11 be damned.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Army gave us separate barracks, separate blood supply, separate latrines. But them European girls didn’t mind us a bit. (then) When we were in Wimbourne, English gal I never laid eyes on patted me right on the butt. Told me she was checking for a tail because the white GI's was saying we were more monkey than human. So we made sure to show ‘em just how human we were every opportunity we got.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: German girls too, huh?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well...one in particular. Ronsel drifts with the memory of Resl, wistful.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Uh oh, I’ve seen that look before. She must’a been something special.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. She was. But that was then. And this is now. I’m back home. Right where I belong. Said with a cut of drunken sarcasm.  89. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - NIGHT Crickets outside as Ronsel lays in bed by candlelight, wi awake. He’s gazing at Resl’s gold necklace and crucifix. Then, with resolve, he stuffs it into a small tin box nex his bed and closes the lid shut. Then he blows out the candle, still wide awake as he tries to forget her. INT. THE MCALLAN FARM —- HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Henry snores loudly. So loudly Laura is awake. She shakes him and he stops. Then Laura settles in and tries to get comfortable. But after a few moments, Henry starts snorin again. Finally, Laura succumbs to the futility and gets u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura exits the house into the moonlight. She is startled when she nearly trips over Jamie, who is passed out with empty bottle of bourbon. Fully clothed and breathing heav from drink, he is peaceful and pitiful all at once.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Nonono, I can’t swim! I can’t swim! Laura turns and sees Jamie writhing in his sleep:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: NO! AHHHH! AHHHHH!!!! Jamie! Jamie wake up! Laura shakes him hard. Jamie shoots to upright, eyes darting. Then he looks to Laura as the sense creeps back into him. A beat, then he starts crying. She pulls him to her and he sinks into her arms. After a few moments, Henry appears in the doorway. Neithe Laura nor Jamie notice him. Henry says nothing. He just stands there watching their embrace, jealousy in his eyes Eventually, Henry moves back into the house. Then Jamie rips himself away from Laura’s embrace:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Jamie... Jamie stumbles toward Henry’s car, gets in and pulls away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Henry's car goes blazing by, swerving. INT. HENRY’S CAR (MOVING) - LATER Jamie dozing at the wheel. He awakes and jerks the truck toward the side of the road. Overshoots, and slips into a ditch. Jamie squinting, flailing, cursing as he strips th gears trying to free the truck.

dialogues.speaker: DAMN
dialogues.text: Jamie shuts off the engine, slumps across the wheel cryin blubbering, incoherent. He falls asleep across the wheel. Headlights still on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Thacker knocking on the truck window. Jamie, red- eyed, stubbled, haggard shoulders a line of drool away. H wakes slowly, drags his sodden gaze to the window. Henry frowns over the Sheriff’s shoulder. Jamie shudders, strug with the car door. Sheriff helps rip it open. Jamie stumb into the light.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: We'll get it hauled out in the morning, Henry. Jamie and Henry clamber out of the ditch in silence. Jami is hungover and haggard.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Henry shakes his head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry hammers repairs while Jamie finishes milking the co When Jamie stands he trips, falls and spills milk everywh Jamie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You think it’s funny spilling good milk?  91.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (slurring) Well you know what they say, no use crying over it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No, especially when it’s somebody else's. Jamie stops grinning and turns sarcastic as he reaches in his pocket and produces some coins and crumpled bills.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I see. What do I owe you, Henry? About a dollar and a half? Let’s just say two to be safe. Jamie pushes the money at him. Henry slaps his hand away the money goes flying. A clumsy, half-hearted fist-fight.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: For Christ’s sake, this ain’t about the money.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Then what do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: For you to be a man!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: One pail of spilled milk and I’m not a man?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're sure not acting like one. Disappear for days at a time doing whatever you damn well please. And when you are here, you’re drunk.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t answer to you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You do when you live in my house and work on my farm.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Oh, well I’m real sorry about that Mr. Boss man. But don’t take it out on me because your little farmer dream ain’t working. Ain’t my fault your crops are getting flooded out.  92.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well you sure as hell ain’t helping matters. It’s like having another goddamn child to look after.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You need to open your eyes, big brother. You’re so busy walking around here like God almighty, so wrapped up in yourself and your damn farm you can’t even see your own wife is miserable.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Or what? Henry clenches his fists and squares up. Jamie stands his ground. But Henry restrains himself.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Know what? You be whatever kind of man you want. Just go do it someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Fine, I’1l go to town.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don’t mean just for the night. In the morning I’m going to Greenville for a few days to see about some livestock. I’11 expect you gone when I get back. They hold a look, neither man seeing clearly through the of anger and pride. Then Henry leaves Jamie in his wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jamie packs his things, frustrated, angry. He reacts w Laura knocks at his open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hi there, will you be here for supper tonight?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (re: the packed bags) Are you going someplace?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Out west probably. Gotta buddy from the war who lives in Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Los Angeles? Jamie, what are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He didn’t tell you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Who didn’t tell me what?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Henry. He kicked me out.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He asked me to leave. I probably had it coming.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That can’t be. He’s just sore about the wreck. Let me talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No, Laura. He’s more than just sore. And it’s probably for the best.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: So just like that? You up and leave? Were you even planning on saying good-bye?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Of course. First bus out doesn’t leave ‘til two.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What about the girls? This will break their little hearts.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I‘1l talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie keeps packing. The suddenness of this new reality i bitter prospect for Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Does your father know?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I'll go down to the river and find the girls. And Pappy... I’1l just leave him a note.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You don’t need to go, Jamie. When Henry cools off he’1l listen to me. Jamie stops packing for a moment and stares at the floor. Then he looks at her, so much hurt in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Laura, I can’t stay here. I feel like I’m suffocating. I can’t explain it...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You don’t need to. Laura runs her hand along his suitcase and wishes she cou run away with him. Jamie tamps his pain, tired of being pathetic. Laura moves to him, close. They gaze at each other for a very long beat, neither wanting to say goodby Then with alarming swiftness, Laura grabs Jamie and kisse him. Deeply. Hungrily. Then suddenly he pushes her away. Both of them breathe heavily, their hearts racing. Then Jamie pulls her close and they kiss again. Clothes get to off as they tumble onto the bed. Jamie and Laura devour e other. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY Florence, Hap, Marlon and Lilly May clean up after breakf Ronsel enters, haggard and sleepless.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: It’s half past nine. You just now getting up? Ronsel shrugs and nods.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You just gon’ lay around all day? While your brothers and sisters work? What’s wrong with you--  95.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY MAY
dialogues.text: You got a letter. Says it’s all the way from Germany.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: What? Hap hands over a worn envelope that’s traveled a long way Ronsel snatches it.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Who’s Resl Braun?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Someone I knew. And Ronsel heads out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Where you going now? Ronsel!

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: I’1l be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grey horizon hints at a coming storm. Ronsel walks along, a swirl of emotion, shaking his head in disbelief he reads the letter. Then he reacts to the rising sound of an APPROACHING TRUC He quickly shoves the letter into his pockets. The truck moving fast. The glint from the windshield prevents us fr seeing the driver. But we hear the engine rev higher as h steps on the gas. Ronsel moves to the shoulder of the road. But the truck swerves in his direction and bears down on him. Ronsel ru and dives into a ditch just as the truck rumbles up and s to a fast stop. Then, surprisingly, Jamie tumbles out, laughing and drunk. He’s got a bottle of whiskey and he looks like absolute hell.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You should’a seen the look on your face.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: It ain’t funny.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Actually, my friend, it was indeed.  96. Ronsel gets up and brushes himself off. Jamie is still smiling. Then soon, Ronsel can’t help but smile too.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: You're crazy you know that, right?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Can’t argue with that. No, sir. Jamie takes a pull from the bottle and plops to the groun mess. Ronsel sees the state he’s in.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Hey. Is something the matter? Jamie gets quiet and picks at the label on the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What’s the worst thing you ever did?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: (after a beat) That lady I told you about. The one at the prison camp.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No, I mean something that hurt somebody real bad. And you knew it was gonna hurt ‘em, but you did it anyway. This time Ronsel gets quiet for a long beat. Then he pull out the letter and a photo and hands it to Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Leaving her. Jamie looks at the picture then reads the letter. Then he reacts and smiles:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Well, I’ll be. Congratulations. You're a father.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: His name’s Franz.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Franz. That’s a good name. (then) So that’s the German girl.  97. Ronsel nods and we finally see the photo. It is of Resl holding a swaddled baby. Jamie hands the photo back to Ronsel and holds up the bottle:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well this calls for a celebration. Here’s to Franz. Jamie takes a swig and hands Ronsel the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: To Franz. Then Ronsel takes a drink and gives the bottle back to Ja

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: So what the hell are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: I have no idea. She wants me to go to Germany.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Long way off. Ronsel nods, he knows. Jamie stares into the distance as Ronsel stares at Franz. Then:

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: What about you? What’s the worst thing you ever done? Jamie looks at him, his mind on Laura and their tryst. Bu Jamie smiles and covers:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Who me? I’m a saint.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I bet. Then there’s a distant THUNDER RUMBLE. The clouds on the horizon are getting darker. Jamie kills the whiskey bottl and tosses it into the ditch. INT. HENRY’S PICK-UP TRUCK - DAY Jamie and Ronsel pass a new bottle and sing in unison:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE/RONSEL
dialogues.text: It don't mean a thing if it ain't got that swing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE/RONSEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Doo-ah, doo-ah, doo-ah, doo-ah, doo- ah, doo-ah, doo-ah. It don't mean a thing all you got -- They both react to an approaching car and stop singing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Oh shit, put your head down. Ronsel ducks. The dust makes it hard to see but the road narrow and soon they pass the oncoming car. Orris drives Pappy rides shotgun. Jamie looks forward and Ronsel keeps his head low. Pappy and Orris crane their necks as the vehicles cross.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: You think they saw us?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Don’t know. INT. HENRY’S PICK-UP TRUCK - DAY Jamie and Ronsel pull up to the Jackson’s shack, both dru

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Here we are. (beat) I'll be leaving town soon and... Well, good luck to you. You’ve been a friend. I want you to know that.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well I want you to know it too. You’re one of the good ones. Jamie hesitates to accept this truth. Ronsel extends a ha Jamie graps it, they shake hard.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hope you find a way to your...to your boy...to your... family.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You too. They hold a look, friends. Jamie extends a hand. They sha  99. INT. THE JACKSON’S CABIN - DAY The RUMBLE OF DISTANT THUNDER. Florence flinches when Ron enters, wobbly and high.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Hi, Momma. She watches him, wants to hug him ask him where he’s been But what comes out is:

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: No. Where is everybody?

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Went up to church. Late service. Ronsel plops onto his cot. Florence wants to talk to him, help him, but he seems so unreachable. Ronsel reaches into his pocket and pulls out the envelope from Resl. He reaches inside and finds nothing. Where’s t letter and the photo? Brow furrowed, he stands and rifles through his other pockets. Not there. Oh shit. Rising panic. He lost it.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Goddammit... No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: What is it son?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: You seen a letter?

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: The letter from Germany?

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Oh God. Let’s just wait. Don’t fret. Wait till your father-- Ronsel busts out of the shack and back into the night.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ronsel? Ronsel!  100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The threat of thunder has turned into reality of pounding rain. Ronsel runs to the spot where he told Jamie about t letter. He looks around desperately. He finds the empty whiskey bottle with the label Jamie picked off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura is in the kitchen. Amanda Leigh and Isabelle are on the floor playing with building blocks. Pappy lingers by window, anxiously waiting.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Goddammit, where is he?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (re: the girls) Mind your language, please.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Just like him. Thinking only of himself. (then) There he is. Outside the truck pulls up, weaving badly. Jamie gets out and stumbles to the house.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drunk again. Jamie enters, rumpled, wet and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Well, hello, dear family.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA LEIGH/ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Uncle Jamie!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Let him dry off first.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Who in the hell was that with you in the truck?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hello, son. I’m glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: On the road. When I saw you driving. Who was that?  101.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Ronsel Jackson. What's it to you?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You care to tell me why that nigger was sitting right next to you like you was two peas in a pod?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Because I was giving him a ride.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: He can ride in the back.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: He can ride wherever I say. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Gimmie a cigarette. I’m out. Jamie stares at him for a beat then pulls out an old pack Lucky Strikes. Pappy snatches them. It’s empty.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ain’t worth a damn, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I do. Jamie wobbles.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Look at mister big war hero. Nothing but a drunk.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Just go.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Want him all to yourself huh, gal? Too bad he’s too liquored up to be any good to you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: I’ve seen the way you sniff after him --

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Pappy.  102.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Henry may be too thick to notice, but I ain’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain as Ronsel trudges up the road. Then he reacts to the crescendo of approaching cars. He turns and sees two sets headlights approaching fast. Ronsel jumps down into the ditch. But instead of passing, the cars pull up and stop. Ronsel is a bit blinded by the headlights and the rain. But soon several figures in whit sheets and hoods pile out of the cars and rush at him. Ronsel runs but they are on him like a pack of dogs. He fights and struggles, landing several hard punches. But h outnumbered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain beats on the roof as Jamie sleeps on his cot. A beat then he is poked awake by Pappy’s cane. Jamie bolts up, startled to see Pappy. Orris Stokes and the Sheriff are behind him in white robes.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What the hell’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Put your boots on and come with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard rain. Orris Stokes’ car pulls up and stops among som other parked cars. Jamie, Pappy, and Orris Stokes get out and move towards the saw mill. We can see torch lights coming from inside the mill. As they go, the Sheriff and Stokes don their white hoods. This gives Jamie pause and stops. But Stokes shoves him along.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Go on. They open the door to the saw mill and enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside are a group of men in KKK garb. In the middle of t mill is Ronsel. He has a burlap sack over his head, a noo around his neck and his hands tied behind him. He’s strun up from a rafter, his tip-toes barely touching the ground One of the white hoods holds the other end of the rope. Another man (DEX) stands nearby with a shotgun.  103.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What’s going on here, Pappy?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: (re: Ronsel) Take it off. Dex moves to Ronsel and yanks the sack off his head. As h eyes adjust to the light we see that Ronsel has been beat

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Good Lord. Turn him loose.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: I said shut up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Like hell I will. Turn him loose, dammit. Stokes pulls his pistol and levels it at Jamie:

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: You best listen, son.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I ain’t your son. And I suggest you either use that thing or point it elsewhere. Jamie readies lunge at Stokes.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Jamie!

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: Bring forth the evidence. One of the white hoods moves forward and brings out the letter and the photograph from Resl. Both Jamie and Ronse see it and sink. The white hood hands it to Pappy. SHERIFF THACKER (CONT’D) You know why you’re here, nigger? (off Ronsel’s silence) I asked you a question. Ronsel stays silent. Sheriff throws a nod to Orris who wa over to Ronsel and slugs him with a left and then a right the ribs. The thuds from the blows force grunts from Rons  104. Jamie winces. But Ronsel stays as cool. He will not show them his fear. Pappy walks up to Ronsel and shows him the letter and the picture of Resl and Franz. Ronsel eyes the photo. SHERIFF THACKER (CONT’D) Did you rut with this woman?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: We know you did it, nigger. We just want to hear you say it. The white hood holding the rope jerks it.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Go on! Say it!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What the hell do you fellows care about some Kraut whore?

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Shut your mouth, nigger lover.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You knew about it. Found the letter in the truck after you gave him a ride.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Those Fraulein cunts got a lot of our boys killed. If Ronsel here left her with a little half-breed bundle of joy to remind her of it, I call it justice. Jamie’s logic lands for a moment and there’s hope.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: Oh you’re good, pretty boy. Too bad you’re full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: How do you even know that Ronsel here, is the father?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Says so right there in the letter.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: That doesn’t mean a damn thing.  105.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Well, let’s ask him, why don’t we? (to Ronsel re: the photo) Are you the father of this, I won’t call it a child, this... abomination?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: Answer him! The noose tightens. Ronsel won’t deny his own son and he Manages to choke out the word:

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: Leviticus 19:19. “Ye shall keep my statutes. Thou shalt not let thy cattle gender with a diverse kind. Thou shalt not sow thy field with mingled seed." The penalty for abomination is death.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Have you all lost your damn minds?! Killing a decorated soldier over an enemy whore?! The man fought for Patton for Godsakes --

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: That’s enough --

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You turn him loose now and maybe I won't go to the law. Otherwise, I swear, you better kill us both. Stokes can’t believe the nerve of Jamie and he moves towa him with the gun.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You gonna betray your own blood over a nigger?! Pappy tries to stand between Stokes and Jamie, but Jamie shoves him out of the way. Stokes points the gun at Jamie Jamie steps up and puts the gun barrel to his own forehea

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Do it. Go on.  105A. The entire room hangs on the tension for a long beat. The quick as a cat, Jamie swipes the gun with one hand and PUNCHES Stokes in the mouth with the other. Stokes’s head snaps back and he stumbles backwards and falls. Jamie quickly turns to Dex who has the shotgun.  106.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drop it, Dex! Dex hesitates and Jamie cocks the hammer.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: He’s bluffing. And half drunk besides.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Shut up, old man.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Point the gun at the nigger. Pappy moves right into Jamie’s eye line, blocking his sho

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He won’t shoot. He don’t have the balls to kill a man up close. Do you, son? Dex points the shotgun at Ronsel. Pappy steps closer to Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Stop right there. I’m warning you.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You not gon’ kill your Pappy. Then one of the white hoods charges at Jamie. Jamie turns and shoots him in the leg. But that was enough to give th others a chance to rush in. Jamie squeezes off another shot that misses before he get tackled. In the subsequent melee, they somehow manage to wrest the gun from Jamie’s hands. But Jamie punches, kicks and gives everything he’s got, fighting like a cornered animal. But soon, they overwhelm him. And they proceed to beat the shit out of him. Jamie and Ronsel lock eyes for a moment during the beatin Then a kick to the head from Stokes. CUT TO BLACK. PAPPY’S VOICE FADES IN, echo-y and distant.  107.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Wake up! Jamie! Wake up dammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie is awakened by a bucket of cold rain water. He is bruised, blurry and dazed. But as focus restores he sees mass of white hoods staring down at him. Among the hoods is Pappy’s face. Jamie recoils and tries push him away but his hands are tied behind his back. Pap yanks him upright and props him against the wall. Jamie s that Ronsel now hangs from a cross-beam, naked and bloodi

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You make one more wrong move these boys are liable to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: (re: Jamie) What do we do with him?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: I told you already. He won’t talk. Ain’t that right, son?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (re: Ronsel) Just let him go.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: You ain’t exactly in a position to make demands.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: He won't go to the law. Not if we make him a part of it.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Nigger still needs to be punished. You let my son, there, decide how.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Alright then. What’ll it be?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I won't do it.  108.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You don’t want him killed? Then decide his punishment.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No. Stokes unsheathes a HUNTING KNIFE:

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: You will. Or I will. Dex moves to Ronsel and puts the shotgun to Ronsel’s head

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: I'll give you a choice. His eyes. His tongue. Or his balls. Choose. (off Jamie’s silence) Choose godammit!

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Dex --

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Alright! Alright... Jamie locks eyes with Ronsel. This is an impossible choic

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF THACKER
dialogues.text: Which is it, boy? Jamie's head drops and he mumbles something.

dialogues.speaker: DOC TURPIN
dialogues.text: Speak up. As Turpin leans in the RISING MUSIC and the SOUNDS OF THE STORM OUTSIDE TAKE OVER. Then in a SERIES OF FLASHES: --Jamie says something to the Sheriff that we cannot hear --Stokes turns towards Ronsel with the knife. --White hoods hold a struggling Ronsel. --Stokes grabs Ronsel by the face and forces his mouth op --Jamie can’t look and he averts his eyes.  109. --Ronsel’s strange muffled screams --Stokes slices and BLOOD spurts from Ronsel’s mouth and stains some of the white robes around him. SMASH TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie is thrown onto his bed, wet, beaten and unconscious Pappy and Orris Stokes glower above him. Stokes drifts ou Pappy frozen, staring at Jamie. He removes his son’s boot Throws a horse blanket over him. Jamie sputters in his sl A confusion of feelings mottle Pappy’s face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hap, Marlon, Florence, and OTHER BLACK DEACONS push the d open and enter the scene of the crucifixion. Ronsel hangs bleeding from the crossbeam, the Black Messiah. Hap and Marlon immediately set to levering him down. Florence’s h goes to her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving rain and howling wind outside. Pappy sleeps peacefully, his breathing deep and steady. A LIGHTNING FL accompanied by THUNDER briefly ILLUMINATES the room. Several beats, then more THUNDER and LIGHTNING and we see Jamie standing by Pappy’s bedside. He stares at Pappy as clinches the pillow in his hands. Then finally he shakes Pappy violently:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Wake up. Pappy jerks awake and squints up at Jamie:

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: The hell are you doing, boy?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I wanted to make sure I looked you in the eye. With that Jamie shoves the pillow onto Pappy’s face. Papp thrashes and claws. Jamie presses harder. Then soon the thrashing weakens. Pappy’s leg kicks become twitches and hands loose from Jamie's. And then Pappy is still. Jamie holds the pillow there for several more beats. Then, slow he pulls it from Pappy’s face. Pappy’s eyes are wide and mouth agape.  110.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, no... A river of blood pools from Ronsel’s mouth as Hap lowers to the floor. Florence wraps his nude body in her headsca Mary Magdalene. Marlon scoops up his brother's legs. Florence touches his chest, howls in sorrow. She cups her hand over his chest. Bomp Bomp Bomp.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I held his heartbeat in my hand. I remember every beat. He was warm and alive... Ronsel stirs and coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Laura KNOCKS on the door. No answer. Perplexed, she pushes the door open and enters She reacts when she sees Pappy eyes wide open, lifeless a frozen in shock.
