Then she reaches out, touches his skin a quickly recoils from the cold. She scans Jamie’s empty bed. Something on the floor catch her eye. She reaches down and picks it up. It’s Pappy’s white hood. Laura holds it up and sees the eye holes and realizes.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s exactly what you think it is. Laura sees Jamie sitting in the corner clutching the pill he smothered Pappy with. She reacts to his beat up face:

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What happened to you? (off his desolate look) What happened, Jamie? Jamie. Jamie reaches into a pocket and fishes out the crumpled p of Resl and Ronsel’s son. Laura looks at it, confused.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Thy got Ronsel. I tried to stop it... there were too many of them...  lll.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What happened Jamie? What did they do to him?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: They made me choose.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Choose what?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I had to.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He’s alive? Jamie shakes his head, twists the pillow in his fists. La looks to Pappy, Jamie finally meets her gaze. Laura gentl pries the pillow from Jamie’s hands. INT. JACKSON CABIN — DAWN The hush of daybreak. Ronsel laid out on the kitchen tabl Florence wipes dried blood from his swollen, bruised body She dabs at the stillness of his face.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE MOVED AND RE-NUMBERED TO SCENE 162
dialogues.text: EXT. THE MCALLAN FARM —- LATER A truck drives up the road and stops. Henry gets out with bag. He waves and nods to the driver. Laura and Jamie mov out towards Henry. Jamie has cleaned up and changed his clothes, but he’s st beat up. Jamie and Laura approach Henry as he kneels at h crops. He flicks a glance at them, more concerned with th cotton.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Got back as soon as I could. If this keeps up we’ll have to replant. Almanac predicted--

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Henry.  112.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (re: Jamie’s bruises) What in the hell happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Henry.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What? Laura looks to Jamie. But Jamie just shakes his head and stares at his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s your father. He died last night.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What? How?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: In his sleep. Peacefully. Henry drops his head as the news washes over him. Then He looks at Jamie and regrets their last exchange.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You alright? (off Jamie’s nod) I’m glad you're still here. Jamie nods then Henry hugs him. Jamie, racked with guilt pain, hugs back. PRELAP the RUMBLE of THUNDER and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LIGHTNING FLASH and we return to the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Hap. Can you help us out here? We need to get this coffin in. Hap pulls his arm away and steps down. Florence spits ove the side of the wagon and glares at the McAllans.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for stopping. Hap takes an end of the rope, Henry eyes Marlon.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe he can help too?  113.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: My son is not getting down outta that wagon. Henry swallows this.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Okay. Henry takes two end of the rope, Hap and Jamie each take and they maneuver the coffin down into the hole. The coff touches bottom and they pull the ropes back up. Henry sta down at the coffin for a beat then:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We forgot to bring a bible. Hap looks to the sky and cocks his head like he’s listeni to something. Then he bows it and pulls a small, tattered bible from inside his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Done this plenty of times.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Hap. But no.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: If he’s willing to we should allow it. He is a man of God.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I say we let him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (after a begrudging beat) Go on then. Hap flips to a certain page as they all bow their heads. beat, then Hap closes the Bible and quotes from memory. H voice is strong and ringing. He’s not trying to comfort t bereaved. He’s sending Pappy to Hell:

dialogues.speaker: HAP
dialogues.text: Man who is born of a woman is of few days and full of trouble. He cometh forth like a flower, and is cut down: he fleeth as a shadow, and continueth not. And dost thou open thine eyes upon such a one, and bringest me into judgment with thee? Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? Not one.  114. Henry frowns, not appreciating the tone or content of the sermon. Laura holds his hand, Jamie looks up:

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For there is hope of a tree, if it be cut down, that it will sprout again. Through the scent of water it will bud like a plant. But man dieth, and wasteth away. As the waters fail from the sea and drieth up, so man lieth down, and riseth not. Till the heavens be no more, they shall not awake, nor be raised out of their sleep. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Amen

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Amen. Henry is silent. His head still down, he starts shovellin angry mounds of dirt onto the grave. Hap tips his hat and makes for the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hap, wait. Jamie moves to where the tarp hangs. He can’t see inside, but he knows who’s in there:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give this to Ronsel? If you see him. Jamie pulls out the photo of Resl and Franz. Florence rea out and takes the photo. Jamie and Florence hold a long look. Jamie’s eyes well up with guilt. Hap manages a forgiving nod then spurs the mule on. Off Jamie watching them go...he looks back at his brother shovelling dirt. L eyes plead with him. Jamie turns away and keeps on walkin lone man on a muddy road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie, small pack slung over his shoulder walks through t grand lobby. He reaches into a pocket, pulls out a flask takes a couple swigs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Whenever Ronsel enters my mind I hope that he is well. We STAY WITH him as he moves outside to... Sunshine. Palm trees. A clear view of the mountains in the distance. Jam squints. The dry heat feels good on his face. Then as he moves off:

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I hope that my Pappy’s untimely death brought the Jackson family some measure of peace. Though I must admit, it brings me none.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I just thank God I still have room in my heart for hope of any kind. 1940's LA noir style. As Jamie smokes a cigarette at an o window with a blinking sign out front. A PRETTY WOMAN pou bourbon. It’s a hot night and she crosses naked to the be with two sweating glasses. Jamie draws on his cigarette t follows her to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But until then I am content to stay perpetually numb. All the while hoping that by some miracle my friend, Ronsel, found happiness. Off Jamie drinking...and hoping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Henry drives his tractor through the field:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A few days after I lost my father, I lost my brother too. The girls took it hard. Frankly, so did I. But, Laura, she understood. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She knew Jamie needed to leave this place. Just like I knew she needed to. My family’s the only real thing that matters to me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a block with other small houses. Amanda Leigh and Isabelle play in the front yard enclosed by a white picke fence.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But I often miss my brother and find myself hoping he’1l come home someday. I just pray he’s not lost forever. Laura waddles out onto the porch and we see that she is V PREGNANT. Henry pulls up in his truck and gets out. The girls see Henry and run to him.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I would never tell Henry the truth about this child. Jamie’s child. That would only serve to clear my conscience, not his. It’s a small bit of dignity that I can give back to him. Though he has no idea I’ve taken it. Henry moves up to the porch and gives Laura a hug and war kiss on the lips. Then he bends and kisses her belly. And for the first time ever, we see Henry truly smile.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I've learned that’s what it is to truly love someone: to give whatever you can while taking what you must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hap and Marlon hitch a NEW MULE to a NEW PLOW in a beauti field.

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This here is the loins of the land. Beautiful black soil made rich by two great rivers and the hand of the Lord himself. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And now, with sweat, toil and the grace of God, we got ourselves a little piece of it. My children got something they can call they own. And can’t nothing change that. Not ever. Hap can see Florence and Lilly May over by a water pump. waves. They wave back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florence works the water pump with Lilly May at her side.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you got children, you got dreams for ‘em. You want ‘em to live they life thinking they can do whatever it is they want to. Florence fills the bucket, Lilly May tries to help but Florence shoos Lilly May towards their newer, nicer HOME. Daffodils ring the steps. Florence wipes her sweaty brow watches as Lilly May perches on the porch, pulls out a notebook, pencils, books : US PERSONNEL OFFICE STENOGRAPH GRADE AND EVALUATION GUIDE. Lilly May sinks into the page

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All three of my children a gift from God. Just let them keep shining, Lord. No matter how hard they try to dim that light, let it shine bright as the sun. EXT. HAP’S WAGON - DAY Ronsel’s face through slotted wood as Hap’s wagon lurches a start. Household goods bump and rattle above him. Jamie voice trailing away.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: .--give this to him...if you see him again? Pooled rain drips down from a tarp, through the cracks on Ronsel’s closed eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My nightmare is always the same. First I’m in a tank wearing a helmet. Then I’m in the back of a car with a burlap sack over my head. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m surrounded by enemies and the stench of their hate is choking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FLOAT past the war torn Brandenburg Gate. A pair of AMERICAN SOLDIERS amble past.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I scream. My lips move and I can feel the strain. But nothing is coming out. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bombed out spire of the Kaiser Wilhelm Church.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But should my story end there? Silenced and defeated? Oppression, fear, deformity. It would take an extraordinary man to beat all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float down a clean residential street.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I would have had to wean myself off laudanum and self-pity. Then I would have had to work the fields with my father while I gathered my courage and saved my money. And then I would have had to swallow my pride and accept help from Army buddies who had learned of my plight. I would have had to take the scholarship to Morehouse College they arranged for me and travel the four hundred miles to Atlanta alone with a little card in my shirt pocket that said ‘mute’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CRISP, SUITED MAN climbs the stairs, checks the address We can’t see his face. Eventually he reaches a door and stares at it for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: RONSEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then finally, I would have had cross the Atlantic yet again. This time not for war. But for love.
